Pielke]] and [[Stephen McIntyre]] criticized the US instrumental temperature record and adjustments to it, and Pielke and others criticized the poor quality siting of a number of weather stations in the United States.<ref>{{Cite journal|first=Christopher A.|last=Davey|last2=Pielke Sr. |first2=Roger A.|journal=Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society|year=2005|volume=86|issue=4|pages=497–504|title=Microclimate Exposures of Surface-Based Weather Stations: Implications For The Assessment of Long-Term Temperature Trends|url=http://climatesci.org/publications/pdf/R-274.pdf |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080910213816/http://climatesci.org/publications/pdf/R-274.pdf |archivedate= 10 September 2008|doi=10.1175/BAMS-86-4-497|bibcode = 2005BAMS...86..497D|ref=harv }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|first=Rezaul|last=Mahmood|author2=Stuart A. Foster|author3=David Logan|journal=International Journal of Climatology|year=2006|volume=26|issue=8|pages=1091–1124|title=The GeoProfile metadata, exposure of instruments, and measurement bias in climatic record revisited |doi=10.1002/joc.1298|bibcode = 2006IJCli..26.1091M|ref=harv }}</ref> In 2007, [[Anthony Watts (blogger)|Anthony Watts]] began a volunteer effort to photographically document the siting quality of these stations.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=Investor's Business Daily|url=http://www.ibdeditorials.com/IBDArticles.aspx?id=267405911624139|title=Fiddler On The Roof|date=22 June 2007 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070815235121/http://www.ibdeditorials.com/IBDArticles.aspx?id=267405911624139 |archivedate= 15 August 2007}}</ref> The ''[[Journal of Geophysical Research]] – Atmospheres'' subsequently published a study by Menne et al. which examined the record of stations picked out by Watts' Surfacestations.org and found that, if anything, the poorly sited stations showed a slight cool bias rather than the warm bias which Watts had anticipated.<ref name=Menne>{{cite journal |last=Menne |first=Matthew J.|author2=Claude N. Williams, Jr. |author3=Michael A. Palecki |year=2010 |title=On the reliability of the U.S. surface temperature record |journal=Journal of Geophysical Research |volume=115 |issue=D11|page=D11108 |doi=10.1029/2009JD013094 |url=http://www1.ncdc.noaa.gov/pub/data/ushcn/v2/monthly/menne-etal2010.pdf |quote=In summary, we find no evidence that the CONUS average temperature trends are inflated due to poor station siting...The reason why station exposure does not play an obvious role in temperature trends probably warrants further investigation. |bibcode=2010JGRD..11511108M |ref=harv}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/blog/2010/jan/27/climate-sceptics-global-warming|title=Climate sceptics distract us from the scientific realities of global warming|last=Cook|first=John|date=27 January 2010 |newspaper=The Guardian|accessdate=5 February 2010|location=London}}</ref>
The [[Berkeley Earth Surface Temperature]] group carried out an independent assessment of land temperature records, which examined issues raised by skeptics, such as the urban heat island effect, poor station quality, and the risk of data selection bias. The preliminary results, made public in October 2011, found that these factors had not biased the results obtained by NOAA, the [[Hadley Centre]] together with the [[Climatic Research Unit]] ([[HadCRUT]]) and NASA's GISS in earlier studies. The group also confirmed that over the past 50 years the land surface warmed by 0.911 °C, and their results closely matched those obtained from these earlier studies. The four papers they had produced had been submitted for peer review.<ref name=Nature1011>{{cite news|url=http://www.nature.com/news/2011/111020/full/news.2011.607.html|title=Different method, same result: global warming is real |author=Jeff Tollefson |work=[[Nature News]]|date=20 October 2011|accessdate=22 October 2011|doi=10.1038/news.2011.607|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120114232522/http://www.nature.com/news/2011/111020/full/news.2011.607.html|deadurl=yes|archivedate=14 January 2012}}</ref><ref name=SciDaily1011>{{cite web|url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2011/10/111021144716.htm|title=Cooling the Warming Debate: Major New Analysis Confirms That Global Warming Is Real|work=[[Science Daily]]|date=21 October 2011|accessdate=22 October 2011}}</ref><ref name=Guardian1011>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2011/oct/20/global-warming-study-climate-sceptics|title=Global warming study finds no grounds for climate sceptics' concerns|author=Ian Sample|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=20 October 2011|accessdate=22 October 2011|location=London}}</ref><ref name=Econ1011>{{cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/node/21533360|title=Climate change: The heat is on|work=[[The Economist]]|date=22 October 2011|accessdate=22 October 2011}}</ref>
==== Tropospheric temperature ==== General circulation models and basic physical considerations predict that in the tropics the temperature of the [[troposphere]] should increase more rapidly than the temperature of the surface. A 2006 report to the [[U.S. Climate Change Science Program]] noted that models and observations agreed on this amplification for monthly and interannual time scales but not for decadal time scales in most observed data sets. Improved measurement and analysis techniques have reconciled this discrepancy: corrected buoy and [[List of climate research satellites|satellite]] surface temperatures are slightly cooler and corrected satellite and [[radiosonde]] measurements of the tropical troposphere are slightly warmer.<ref> {{cite journal |first1= B. D. |last1= Santer |first2= P. W. |last2= Thorne |first3= L. |last3= Haimberger |author4= K. E. Taylor |author5=T. M. L. Wigley |author6=J. R. Lanzante |author7=S. Solomon |author8=M. Free |author9=P. J. Gleckler |author10=P. D. Jones |author11=T. R. Karl |author12=S. A. Klein |author13=C. Mears |author14=D. Nychka |author15=G. A. Schmidt |author16=S. C. Sherwood |author17=F. J. Wentz |title= Consistency of modelled and observed temperature trends in the tropical troposphere |journal= International Journal of Climatology |volume= 28 |issue= 13 |pages= 1703–22 |year= 2008 |doi= 10.1002/joc.1756 |bibcode= 2008IJCli..28.1703S |url= https://www.gfdl.noaa.gov/bibliography/related_files/bds0801.pdf |ref= harv }}</ref> [[Satellite temperature measurements]] show that tropospheric temperatures are increasing with "rates similar to those of the surface temperature", leading the IPCC to conclude that this discrepancy is reconciled.<ref> {{Cite book |author= IPCC |chapter= Summary for Policymakers |title=Climate Change 2007: The Physical Science Basis. Contribution of Working Group I to the Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change |chapter-url= http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/spm.html |at= [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/spmsspm-direct-observations.html Direct Observations of Recent Climate Change] |ref= harv |postscript= <!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}} }}, in {{Harvnb|IPCC AR4 WG1|2007}}.</ref>
==== Antarctica cooling ==== {{Main|Antarctica cooling controversy}}
[[File:Antarctic Temperature Trend 1981-2007.jpg|thumb|Antarctic Skin (the roughly top millimeter of land, sea, snow, or ice) temperature trends between 1981 and 2007, based on thermal infrared observations made by a series of NOAA satellite sensors; note that they do not necessarily reflect air temperature trends.]] There has been a public dispute regarding the apparent contradiction in the observed behavior of [[Antarctica]], as opposed to the global rise in temperatures measured elsewhere in the world. This became part of the public debate in the global warming controversy, particularly between advocacy groups of both sides in the public arena, as well as the popular media.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2002/02/04/MN159039.DTL | work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]] |title=Media goofed on Antarctic data / Global warming interpretation irks scientists | first=Keay | last=Davidson |date=4 February 2002|accessdate=13 April 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/2002/0118/p02s01-usgn.html|title=Guess what? Antarctica's getting colder, not warmer|author=Peter N. Spotts |work=[[The Christian Science Monitor]]|date=18 January 2002|accessdate=13 April 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/05/03/us/ozone-hole-is-now-seen-as-a-cause-for-antarctic-cooling.html| work=[[The New York Times]] | title=Ozone Hole Is Now Seen as a Cause for Antarctic Cooling | first=Kenneth | last=Chang | date=3 May 2002 |accessdate=13 April 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://epw.senate.gov/speechitem.cfm?party=rep&id=264027|title=America Reacts To Speech Debunking Media Global Warming Alarmism|publisher=U.S. Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works|date=28 September 2006|accessdate=13 April 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130305155142/http://epw.senate.gov/speechitem.cfm?party=rep&id=264027|archivedate=5 March 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2002/01/0125_020125_antarcticaclimate.html|title=Antarctica Gives Mixed Signals on Warming|author=Bijal P. Trivedi|work=[[National Geographic (magazine)|National Geographic]]|date=25 January 2002|accessdate=13 April 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/science/science-news/3289934/Antarctic-cools-in-warmer-world.html| work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] | location=London | title=Antarctic cools in warmer world | first=David | last=Derbyshire | date=14 January 2002 |accessdate=13 April 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://archives.cnn.com/2002/TECH/science/01/25/antarctica.hot.cold/index.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120609114704/http://articles.cnn.com/2002-01-25/tech/antarctica.hot.cold_1_british-antarctic-survey-west-antarctic-ice-sheet-warming?_s=PM%3ATECH |archivedate= 9 June 2012 |publisher=[[CNN]] |title=Scientific winds blow hot and cold in Antarctica |date=25 January 2002 |accessdate=13 April 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/04/02/science/melting-freezing-antarctica-deciphering-contradictory-climate-patterns-largely.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm| work=[[The New York Times]] | title=The Melting (Freezing) of Antarctica; Deciphering Contradictory Climate Patterns Is Largely a Matter of Ice | first=Kenneth | last=Chang | date=2 April 2002 |accessdate=13 April 2013}}</ref>
In contrast to the popular press, there is no evidence of a corresponding controversy in the scientific community. Observations unambiguously show the [[Antarctic Peninsula]] to be warming. The trends elsewhere show both warming and cooling but are smaller and dependent on season and the timespan over which the trend is computed.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Chapman WL, Walsh JE |title=A Synthesis of Antarctic Temperatures |journal=Journal of Climate |volume=20 |issue=16 |pages=4096–4117 |year=2007 |doi=10.1175/JCLI4236.1|bibcode = 2007JCli...20.4096C |ref=harv }}</ref> A study released in 2009, combined historical weather station data with satellite measurements to deduce past temperatures over large regions of the continent, and these temperatures indicate an overall warming trend. One of the paper's authors stated "We now see warming is taking place on all seven of the earth's continents in accord with what models predict as a response to greenhouse gases."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/01/22/science/earth/22climate.html?ref=science | author=Kenneth Chang | title=Warming in Antarctica Looks Certain|newspaper=The New York Times | date=21 January 2009 | accessdate=13 April 2013| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141113191509/http://www.nytimes.com/2009/01/22/science/earth/22climate.html?ref=science |archivedate=13 November 2014 | deadurl= no}}</ref> According to 2011 paper by Ding, et al., "The Pacific sector of Antarctica, including both the Antarctic Peninsula and continental West Antarctica, has experienced substantial warming in the past 30 years."<ref>{{cite journal|last=Ding|first=Qinghua|author2=Eric J. Steig |author3=David S. Battisti |author4=Marcel Küttel |title=Winter warming in West Antarctica caused by central tropical Pacific warming|journal=Nature Geoscience|date=10 April 2011|volume=4|pages=398–403|doi=10.1038/ngeo1129|url=http://www.nature.com/ngeo/journal/v4/n6/full/ngeo1129.html?WT.ec_id=NGEO-201106|accessdate=12 January 2012|issue=6|bibcode=2011NatGe...4..398D|ref=harv|citeseerx=10.1.1.459.8689}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/science/cold-science/2002-01-13-antarctic-cooling.htm | work=[[USA Today]]|title=Antarctic cooling pushing life closer to the edge | date=16 January 2002 | accessdate=13 April 2013}}</ref>
This controversy began with the misinterpretation of the results of a 2002 paper by Doran et al.,<ref name=Doran02/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.montana.edu/lkbonney/DOCS/Publications/DoranEtAl2002ClimteCooling.pdf|archive-url=https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20120712222502/http://www.montana.edu/lkbonney/DOCS/Publications/DoranEtAl2002ClimteCooling.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=12 July 2012|author=Doran|title=Antarctic climate cooling and terrestrial ecosystem response|publisher=[[University of Illinois at Chicago]]|date=13 January 2002|accessdate=13 April 2013|display-authors=etal|df=dmy-all}} PDF version: advance online publication Letters to Science (archived original)</ref> which found "Although previous reports suggest slight recent continental warming, our spatial analysis of Antarctic meteorological data demonstrates a net cooling on the Antarctic continent between 1966 and 2000, particularly during summer and autumn."<ref name=Doran02/> Later the controversy was popularized by [[Michael Crichton]]'s 2004 fiction novel [[State of Fear]],<ref>{{Cite book | last = Crichton | first = Michael | year = 2004 | title = State of Fear| publisher = [[HarperCollins]] |location=New York| isbn = 978-0-06-621413-9| page = 109|language=}} First Edition</ref> who advocated skepticism in global warming.<ref name=Crichton01>{{cite web |url=http://www.pe.tamu.edu/DL_Program/graduate_seminar_series/Documents/MichaelCrichton_global%20warming.pdf |author=[[Michael Crichton]] |title=The Case for Skepticism in Global Warming |publisher=Michael Crichton The official site |date=25 January 2005 |accessdate=13 April 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140227175954/http://www.pe.tamu.edu/DL_Program/graduate_seminar_series/Documents/MichaelCrichton_global%20warming.pdf# |archive-date=27 February 2014 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} Speech at the National Press Club, Washington, D.C. (restored from archived copy)</ref><ref name=Crichton02>{{cite web|url=http://www.epw.senate.gov/hearing_statements.cfm?id=246766| author=[[Michael Crichton]] |title=Statement of Michael Crichton, M.D. – The Role of Science in Environmental Policy-Making |publisher=U.S. Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works| date=28 September 2005 | accessdate=13 April 2013}} Testimony before the Committee on Environment and Public Works, Washington, D.C.</ref> This novel has a [[docudrama]] plot based upon the idea that there is a deliberately alarmist conspiracy behind [[global warming activism]]. One of the characters argues "data show that one relatively small area called the Antarctic Peninsula is melting and [[Ice calving|calving]] huge icebergs... but the continent as a whole is getting colder, and the ice is getting thicker." As a basis for this plot twist, Crichton cited the peer reviewed scientific article by Doran, et al.<ref name=Doran02>{{cite journal |author=Doran PT |title=Antarctic climate cooling and terrestrial ecosystem response |journal=Nature |volume=415 |issue=6871 |pages=517–20 |date=January 2002 |pmid=11793010 |doi=10.1038/nature710 |url=http://www.uic.edu/classes/geol/eaes102/Doran.pdf |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041211081457/http://www.uic.edu/classes/geol/eaes102/Doran.pdf |archivedate=11 December 2004 |author2=Priscu JC |author3=Lyons WB |display-authors=3 |last4=Walsh |first4=John E. |last5=Fountain |first5=Andrew G. |last6=McKnight |first6=Diane M. |last7=Moorhead |first7=Daryl L. |last8=Virginia |first8=Ross A. |last9=Wall |first9=Diana H. |first10=Gary |last10=D. |first11=Christian |last11=H. |ref=harv}}</ref> [[Peter Doran]], the lead author of the paper cited by Crichton, stated "... our results have been misused as 'evidence' against global warming by Crichton in his novel 'State of Fear'... 'Our study did find that 58 percent of Antarctica cooled from 1966 to 2000. But during that period, the rest of the continent was warming. And climate models created since our paper was published have suggested a link between the lack of significant warming in Antarctica and the ozone hole over that continent."<ref>{{Cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/07/27/opinion/27doran.html?_r=0| author=[[Peter Doran]]|title=Cold, Hard Facts |newspaper=The New York Times | date=27 July 2006 | accessdate=13 August 2013}}</ref>
=== Climate sensitivity === As defined by the IPCC, [[climate sensitivity]] is the "equilibrium temperature rise that would occur for a doubling of {{CO2}} concentration above pre-industrial levels".<ref>IPCC, [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/annexessglossary-a-d.html Glossary A-D]: "Climate Sensitivity", in {{Harvnb|IPCC AR4 SYR|2007}}.</ref> In its 2007 Fourth Assessment Report, IPCC said that climate sensitivity is "likely to be in the range 2 to 4.5 °C with a best estimate of about 3 °C".<ref>[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/mains2-3.html SYR 2.3: Climate sensitivity and feedbacks]</ref>
Using a combination of surface temperature history and ocean heat content, [[Stephen E. Schwartz]] has proposed an estimate of [[climate sensitivity]] of 1.9 ± 1.0 K for doubled {{Co2}}.,<ref>[http://www.ecd.bnl.gov/steve/pubs/HeatCapCommentResponse.pdf Response to Comments on "Heat capacity, time constant, and sensitivity of Earth's climate system"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080703194056/http://www.ecd.bnl.gov/steve/pubs/HeatCapCommentResponse.pdf# |date=3 July 2008 }}. Accepted for publication in Journal of Geophysical Research</ref> revised upwards from 1.1 ± 0.5 K.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Schwartz |first=Stephen E. |title=Heat Capacity, Time Constant and Sensitivity of Earth's Climate System |journal=Journal of Geophysical Research |volume=112 |issue=D24 |pages=D24S05 |year=2007 |url=http://www.ecd.bnl.gov/steve/pubs/HeatCapacity.pdf |doi=10.1029/2007JD008746 |ref=harv |bibcode=2007JGRD..11224S05S |access-date=10 September 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928025217/http://www.ecd.bnl.gov/steve/pubs/HeatCapacity.pdf# |archive-date=28 September 2007 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Grant Foster, [[James Annan]], [[Gavin Schmidt]], and [[Michael E. Mann]]<ref>[http://www.jamstec.go.jp/frsgc/research/d5/jdannan/comment_on_schwartz.pdf Comment on 'Heat Capacity, Time Constant, and Sensitivity of Earth’s Climate System'], Schwartz ''et al.'' ''Journal of Geophysical Research'' DRAFT September 2007</ref><ref>[http://www.realclimate.org/index.php/archives/2007/09/climate-insensitivity/ Climate Insensitivity] RealClimate September 2007</ref> argue that there are errors in both versions of Schwartz's analysis. [[Petr Chylek]] and co-authors have also proposed low climate sensitivity to doubled {{Co2}}, estimated to be 1.6 K ± 0.4 K.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Chylek |first=P. |last2=Lohmann |first2=U. |last3=Dubey |first3=M. |last4=Mishchenko |first4=M. |last5=Kahn|first5=R. |title=Aerosol Optical Depth, Climate Sensitivity and Global Warming |journal=AGU Fall Meeting Abstracts |volume=2007 |pages=A21H–04 |accessdate=|bibcode=2007AGUFM.A21H..04C|year=2007 }}</ref>
In January 2013 widespread publicity was given to work led by Terje Berntsen of the [[University of Oslo]], Julia Hargreaves of the Research Institute for Global Change in Yokohama, and Nic Lewis, an independent climate scientist, which reportedly found lower climate sensitivities than IPCC estimates and the suggestion that there is a 90% probability that doubling {{CO2}} emissions will increase temperatures by lower values than those estimated by the climate models used by the IPCC was featured in news outlets including ''[[The Economist]]''.<ref name=Econ033013/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2013/01/130125103927.htm|title=Global Warming Less Extreme Than Feared? New Estimates from a Norwegian Project On Climate Calculations |author=The Research Council of Norway|publisher=[[Science Daily]]|date=25 January 2013|accessdate=7 April 2013}}</ref> This premature announcement came from a preliminary news release about a study which had not yet been peer reviewed.<ref name="dotearth.blogs.nytimes.com">{{cite news | last = Revkin | first = Andrew | title = When Publicity Precedes Peer Review in Climate Science | url = http://dotearth.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/01/28/when-publicity-precedes-peer-review-in-climate-science-part-one/ | publisher = The New York Times DotEarth blog | accessdate = 22 July 2013 | date=28 January 2013}}</ref> The Center for International Climate and Environmental Research, Oslo (CICERO) issued a statement that they were involved with the relevant research project, and the news story was based on a report submitted to the research council which included both published and unpublished material. The highly publicised figures came from work still undergoing peer review, and CICERO would wait until they had been published in a journal before disseminating the results.<ref name="cicero 28 January 2013">{{cite web | title = Unpublished estimates of climate sensitivity | url = http://cicero.uio.no/webnews/index_e.aspx?id=11856 | publisher = CICERO | date = 28 January 2013 | accessdate = 22 July 2013 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20130626000128/http://www.cicero.uio.no/webnews/index_e.aspx?id=11856# | archive-date = 26 June 2013 | dead-url = yes | df = dmy-all }}</ref>
=== Infrared iris hypothesis === In 2001, [[Richard Lindzen]] proposed a system of compensating meteorological processes involving clouds that tend to stabilize climate change; he tagged this the "[[Iris hypothesis]], or "Infrared Iris".<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1175/1520-0477(2001)082<0417:DTEHAA>2.3.CO;2|author1=Richard S. Lindzen |author2=Ming-Dah Chou |author3=Arthur Y. Hou |journal=[[Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society]] |volume=82 |issue=3 |date=March 2001 |pages=417–432 |url=http://www-eaps.mit.edu/faculty/lindzen/adinfriris.pdf|title=Does the Earth Have an Adaptive Infrared Iris?|format=PDF |bibcode=2001BAMS...82..417L|ref=harv}}</ref> This work has been discussed in a number of papers<ref>Ari Jokimäki, 2009, List of [http://agwobserver.wordpress.com/2009/11/13/papers-on-the-iris-hypothesis-of-lindzen/ Papers on the iris hypothesis of Lindzen] (Retrieved 26 March 2012)</ref>
[[Roy Spencer (meteorologist)|Roy Spencer]] ''et al.'' suggested "a net reduction in radiative input into the ocean-atmosphere system" in tropical intraseasonal oscillations "may potentially support" the idea of an "Iris" effect, although they point out that their work is concerned with much shorter time scales.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Cloud and radiation budget changes associated with tropical intraseasonal oscillations |author=Spencer, Roy W., Braswell, William D., Christy, John R. & Hnilo, Justin |journal=Geophysical Research Letters |volume=34 |issue=15 |pages=L15707 |doi=10.1029/2007GL029698 |year=2007 |url=http://www.weatherquestions.com/Spencer_07GRL.pdf |format=PDF |bibcode=2007GeoRL..3415707S |ref=harv |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080509103925/http://www.weatherquestions.com/Spencer_07GRL.pdf |archivedate=9 May 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Other analyses have found that the iris effect is a ''positive'' feedback rather than the negative feedback proposed by Lindzen.<ref>{{cite journal| journal=Journal of Climate |year=2002 |volume=15| issue=1 |pages=3–7 |title=The iris hypothesis: a negative or positive cloud feedback? |author1=Bing Lin |author2=Bruce A. Wielicki |author3=Lin H. Chambers |author4=Yongxiang Hu |author5=Kuan-Man Xu |doi=10.1175/1520-0442(2002)015<0003:TIHANO>2.0.CO;2 |bibcode=2002JCli...15....3L| issn=1520-0442| ref=harv}}</ref>
=== Temperature projections === [[File:GISTEMPvsHansen1988.png|thumb|right|[[James Hansen]]'s 1988 climate model projections compared with the [[GISS]] measured temperature record<ref name="RC12" />]] [[File:GISTEMPvsIPCC1990.png|thumb|right|IPCC AR4 projections compared to the GISS temperature record<ref name="RC12" />]] [[James Hansen]]'s 1984 climate model projections versus observed temperatures are updated each year by Dr Mikako Sato of Columbia University.<ref>http://www.columbia.edu/~mhs119/Temperature/T_moreFigs/PNAS_GTCh_Fig2.pdf {{full citation needed|date=November 2012}}</ref> The [[RealClimate]] website provides an annual update comparing both Hansen's 1988 model projections and the [[IPCC Fourth Assessment Report]] (AR4) climate model projections with observed temperatures recorded by [[GISS]] and [[HadCRUT]]. The measured temperatures show continuing global warming.<ref name="RC12">http://www.realclimate.org/index.php/archives/2012/02/2011-updates-to-model-data-comparisons/ {{full citation needed|date=November 2012}}</ref>
Conventional projections of future temperature rises depend on estimates of future anthropogenic GHG emissions (see [[Special Report on Emissions Scenarios|SRES]]), those [[Climate change feedback|positive and negative climate change feedbacks]] that have so far been incorporated into the models, and the [[climate sensitivity]]. Models referenced by the [[Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change]] (IPCC) predict that global temperatures are likely to increase by 1.1 to 6.4 °C (2.0 to 11.5 °F) between 1990 and 2100. Others have proposed that temperature increases may be higher than IPCC estimates. One theory is that the climate may reach a "[[Tipping point (climatology)|tipping point]]" where positive feedback effects lead to runaway global warming; such feedbacks include decreased reflection of solar radiation as sea ice melts, exposing darker seawater, and the potential release of large volumes of methane from thawing permafrost.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.commondreams.org/headlines05/0916-09.htm |title=Global Warming 'Past the Point of No Return' |author=Steve Connor |newspaper=[[The Independent]] |date=16 September 2005 |accessdate=7 September 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070203231238/http://www.commondreams.org/headlines05/0916-09.htm |archivedate=3 February 2007 }}</ref> In 1959, Dr. Bert Bolin, in a speech to the National Academy of Sciences, predicted that by the year 2000, there would be a 25% increase in carbon dioxide in the atmosphere compared to the levels in 1859. The actual increase by 2000 was about 29%.<ref>Science News, 9 May 2009{{full citation needed|date=November 2012}}</ref>
[[David Orrell]] or [[Henk Tennekes]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalpost.com/story.html?id=9bc9a7c6-2729-4d07-9629-807f1dee479f&k=0|title=The limits of predictability|author=[[Lawrence Solomon]]|accessdate=23 July 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130723201219/http://www.nationalpost.com/story.html?id=9bc9a7c6-2729-4d07-9629-807f1dee479f&k=0|archivedate=23 July 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> say that climate change cannot be accurately predicted. Orrell says that the range of future increase in temperature suggested by the IPCC rather represents a social consensus in the climate community, but adds "we are having a dangerous effect on the climate".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.postpythagorean.com/FAQ.html|title=Frequently asked questions on Apollo's Arrow/The Future of Everything, by David Orrell|author=David Orrell |accessdate=11 September 2007}}</ref> [[File:Global Temperature Anomaly.svg|thumb|left|global mean land-ocean temperature changes from 1880, relative to the 1951–1980 mean (source: [http://data.giss.nasa.gov/gistemp/ NASA GISS])]] A 2007 study by [[David Douglass (physicist)|David Douglass]] and coworkers, concluded that the 22 most commonly used [[global climate model]]s used by the IPCC were unable to accurately predict accelerated warming in the [[troposphere]] although they did match actual surface warming, concluding "projections of future climate based on these models should be viewed with much caution". This result went against a similar study of 19 models which found that discrepancies between model predictions and actual temperature were likely due to measurement errors.<ref name="sciencedaily_1207">{{cite web|url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2007/12/071211101623.htm|title=New Study Increases Concerns About Climate Model Reliability|accessdate=4 April 2008 |date=20 December 2007 |publisher=Sciencedaily.com}}{{full citation needed|date=November 2012}}</ref>
In a [[NASA]] report published in January 2013, Hansen and Sato noted "the 5-year mean global temperature has been flat for a decade, which we interpret as a combination of natural variability and a slowdown in the growth rate of the net climate forcing."<ref name=Econ033013>{{cite news|url=https://www.economist.com/news/science-and-technology/21574461-climate-may-be-heating-up-less-response-greenhouse-gas-emissions?frsc=dg|title=A sensitive matter|work=[[The Economist]]|date=30 March 2013|accessdate=7 April 2013}}</ref><ref name=Flat201012>{{cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/pdf/719139main_2012_GISTEMP_summary.pdf|title=Global Temperature Update Through 2012|author1=J. Hansen |author2=M. Sato |author3=R. Ruedy |publisher=[[NASA]]|date=15 January 2013|accessdate=7 April 2013}}</ref> Ed Hawkins, of the [[University of Reading]],<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.vox.com/2016/8/26/12637438/new-climate-image-old-climate-trends |title=Scientist finds clever new way to represent same old depressing climate trends |author=David Roberts |date=August 26, 2016 |website=vox.com |publisher=[[Vox (website)|Vox]] |access-date=August 30, 2016 |quote=}}</ref> stated that the "surface temperatures since 2005 are already at the low end of the range of projections derived from 20 climate models. If they remain flat, they will fall outside the models' range within a few years."<ref name=Econ033013/><ref>{{cite journal|author=Stott, P., Good, P., Jones, G., Gillett, N. and Hawkins, E|year=2013|title=The upper end of climate model temperature projections is inconsistent with past warming|journal=[[Environmental Research Letters]]|volume=8|issue=1|page=014024|bibcode=2013ERL.....8a4024S|doi=10.1088/1748-9326/8/1/014024|ref=harv}} Available on line here [http://centaur.reading.ac.uk/31125/1/1748-9326_8_1_014024.pdf], see Figure 4.</ref> Using the long-term temperature trends for the earth scientists and statisticians conclude that it continues to warm through time.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/11/science/earth/what-to-make-of-a-climate-change-plateau.html ''What to Make of a Warming Plateau''] 10 June 2013 ''The New York Times''</ref>
=== Forecasts confidence === The IPCC states it has increased confidence in forecasts coming from General Circulation Models or GCMs. Chapter 8 of AR4 reads: <blockquote>''There is considerable confidence that climate models provide credible quantitative estimates of future climate change, particularly at continental scales and above. This confidence comes from the foundation of the models in accepted physical principles and from their ability to reproduce observed features of current climate and past climate changes. Confidence in model estimates is higher for some climate variables (e.g., temperature) than for others (e.g., precipitation). Over several decades of development, models have consistently provided a robust and unambiguous picture of significant climate warming in response to increasing greenhouse gases.''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ipcc.ch/pdf/assessment-report/ar4/wg1/ar4-wg1-chapter8.pdf |title=Climate Models and Their Evaluation |format=PDF |accessdate=29 August 2010}}{{full citation needed|date=November 2012}}</ref></blockquote>
Certain scientists, skeptics and otherwise, believe this confidence in the models' ability to predict future climate is not earned.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skeptic.com/the_magazine/featured_articles/v14n01_climate_of_belief.html|title=Skeptic: The Magazine: A Climate of Belief|date=2011-02-23}}{{full citation needed|date=November 2012}}</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20080820155631/http://climatesci.org/2008/04/23/comment-on-real-climates-post-on-the-relevance-of-the-sensitivity-of-initial-conditions-in-the-ipcc-models/ Climate Science: Roger Pielke Sr. Research Group News » Comment On Real Climate's Post On The Relevance Of The Sensitivity Of Initial Conditions In The IPCC Models]{{full citation needed|date=November 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.itia.ntua.gr/getfile/864/2/documents/2008HSJClimPredictions.pdf|title=On the credibility of climate predictions|format=PDF|accessdate=29 December 2008}}{{full citation needed|date=November 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|url=http://marketing.wharton.upenn.edu/documents/research/Warmaudit31%205.pdf|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100620221122/http://marketing.wharton.upenn.edu/documents/research/Warmaudit31%205.pdf |archivedate=20 June 2010 | title = Global Warming: Forecasts by Scientists Versus Scientific Forecasts |author1=Kesten C. Greene |author2=J. Scott Armstrong | journal = Energy & Environment | volume = 18 | pages = 997–1021 | year = 2007 |doi=10.1260/095830507782616887|issue=7|ref=harv}}</ref>
===Arctic sea ice decline=== {{Main|Arctic sea ice decline}} {{Multiple image|direction=vertical|align=right|image1=2007 Arctic Sea Ice.jpg|image2=|width=300|caption1=[[Arctic ice pack#Extent and volume of sea ice and their trends|arctic sea ice]] as of 2007 compared to 2005 and also compared to 1979–2000 average|caption2=Northern Hemisphere ice trends}}
Following the (then) record low of the arctic sea ice extend in 2007,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://arctic.atmos.uiuc.edu/cryosphere/|title=New historic sea ice minimum|publisher=The Cryosphere Today|author=William Chapman|date=9 August 2007|accessdate=11 September 2007}}</ref> [[Mark Serreze]], the director of US National Snow and Ice Data Center, stated "If you asked me a couple of years ago when the Arctic could lose all of its ice then I would have said 2100, or 2070 maybe. But now I think that 2030 is a reasonable estimate."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2007/sep/04/climatechange|title=Loss of Arctic ice leaves experts stunned|author=David Adam|newspaper=The Guardian |date=4 September 2007|accessdate=7 September 2007 | location=London}}</ref> In 2012, during another record low, [[Peter Wadhams]] of [[Cambridge University]] predicted a possible final collapse of Arctic sea ice in summer months around 2016.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2012/sep/17/arctic-collapse-sea-ice | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=John | last=Vidal | title=Climate change (Environment),Environment,Sea ice (environment),Polar regions (Environment),Arctic (News),World news, Geoengineering (environment),Carbon emissions (Environment),Climate change (Science),Science | date=17 September 2012}}</ref>
Antarctic and Arctic sea ice extent are available on a daily basis from the National Snow & Ice Data Center.<ref>http://nsidc.org/arcticseaicenews/2012/01/ {{citation needed|date=July 2012}}</ref>
=== Data archiving and sharing === {{Main|Hockey stick controversy}} Scientific journals and funding agencies generally require authors of peer-reviewed research to provide information on [[Scientific data archiving|archives of data]] and share sufficient [[Data sharing|data and methods]] necessary for a scientific expert on the topic to reproduce the work.{{Citation needed|date=March 2016}}
In political controversy over the 1998 and 1999 [[Temperature record of the past 1000 years|historic temperature reconstructions]] widely publicised as the "hockey stick graphs", [[Michael E. Mann|Mann]], [[Raymond S. Bradley|Bradley]] and [[Malcolm K. Hughes|Hughes]] as authors of the studies were sent letters on 23 June 2005 from Rep. [[Joe Barton]], chairman of the [[United States House Committee on Energy and Commerce|House Committee on Energy and Commerce]] and [[Ed Whitfield]], Chairman of the [[United States House Energy Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations|Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations]], demanding full records on the research.<ref name="CHE 505">{{Cite journal |url=http://chronicle.com/article/Congressman-Demands-Complete/121447/ |title=Congressman Demands Complete Records on Climate Research by 3 Scientists Who Support Theory of Global Warming — Archives |author=Richard Monastersky |date=1 July 2005 |newspaper=[[The Chronicle of Higher Education]] |accessdate=4 March 2011}}</ref><ref name="urlThe Committee on Energy and Commerce">{{cite web |url=http://energycommerce.house.gov/108/Letters/06232005_1570.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110410114105/http://energycommerce.house.gov/108/Letters/06232005_1570.htm |archivedate=10 April 2011 |title=The Committee on Energy and Commerce, Joe Barton, Chairman |date=23 June 2005 |work=Letters Requesting Information Regarding Global Warming Studies |publisher=U.S. House of Representatives |accessdate=4 March 2011}}</ref><ref name="Barton to Mann">{{cite web |url=http://energycommerce.house.gov/108/Letters/062305_Mann.pdf |title=letter to Dr. Michael Mann |author=Joe Barton |authorlink=Joe Barton |author2=[[Ed Whitfield]] |date= 23 June 2005 |publisher=[[United States House Committee on Energy and Commerce]] |accessdate=4 March 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120207152418/http://energycommerce.house.gov/108/Letters/062305_Mann.pdf |deadurl=yes |archivedate=7 February 2012 }}</ref> The letters told the scientist to provide not just data and methods, but also personal information about their finances and careers, information about grants provided to the institutions they had worked for, and the exact computer codes used to generate their results.<ref name="wapo Witches">{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/07/22/AR2005072201658.html |title=Hunting Witches |author=editorial |date=23 July 2005 |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |quote= |accessdate=4 March 2011}}</ref>
[[Sherwood Boehlert]], chairman of the [[United States House Committee on Science, Space and Technology|House Science Committee]], told his fellow Republican Joe Barton it was a "misguided and illegitimate investigation" seemingly intended to "intimidate scientists rather than to learn from them, and to substitute congressional political review for scientific review". The [[United States National Academy of Sciences|U.S. National Academy of Sciences]] (NAS) president [[Ralph J. Cicerone]] wrote to Barton proposing that the NAS should appoint an independent panel to investigate. Barton dismissed this offer.<ref name="urlGOP Face Off">{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/07/17/AR2005071701056.html |title=GOP Chairmen Face Off on Global Warming |author=Juliet Eilperin |date=18 July 2005 |newspaper=The Washington Post |quote= |accessdate=4 March 2011}}</ref><ref name="Waxman's letter">{{cite web |url=http://www.henrywaxman.house.gov/UploadedFiles/Letter_to_Chairman_Barton.pdf |title=Letter to Chairman Barton |author=Henry A. Waxman |authorlink=Henry A. Waxman |date=1 July 2005 |publisher=Henry Waxman House of Representatives website |quote= |accessdate=4 March 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120314092100/http://www.henrywaxman.house.gov/UploadedFiles/Letter_to_Chairman_Barton.pdf |deadurl=yes|archivedate=14 March 2012}}</ref>
On 15 July, Mann wrote giving his detailed response to Barton and Whitfield. He emphasised that the full data and necessary methods information was already publicly available in full accordance with [[National Science Foundation]] (NSF) requirements, so that other scientists had been able to reproduce their work. NSF policy was that computer codes are considered the intellectual property of researchers and are not subject to disclosure, but notwithstanding these property rights, the program used to generate the original MBH98 temperature reconstructions had been made available at the Mann et al. public [[File Transfer Protocol|FTP]] site.<ref name="urlwww.realclimate.org">{{cite web |url=http://www.realclimate.org/Mann_response_to_Barton.pdf |title=Letter to Chairman Barton and Chairman Whitfield |author=Michael E. Mann |authorlink=Michael E. Mann |date=15 July 2005 |publisher=RealClimate |quote= |accessdate=4 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727205617/http://www.realclimate.org/Mann_response_to_Barton.pdf |archivedate=27 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}<br>{{cite web |url=http://www.realclimate.org/index.php/archives/2005/07/barton-and-the-hockey-stick/ |title=Scientists respond to Barton |author=Gavin Schmidt |authorlink=Gavin Schmidt |author2=[[Stefan Rahmstorf]] |date=18 July 2005 |publisher=RealClimate |quote= |accessdate=4 March 2011 }}</ref>
Many scientists protested about Barton's demands.<ref name="urlGOP Face Off" /><ref name="20 scientists">{{cite web |url=http://www.realclimate.org/Scientists_to_Barton.pdf |title=letter to Chairman Barton and Chairman Whitfield |author=20 scientists as listed |date=15 July 2005 |publisher=RealClimate |quote= |accessdate=4 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727205805/http://www.realclimate.org/Scientists_to_Barton.pdf |archivedate=27 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[Alan I. Leshner]] wrote to him on behalf of the [[American Association for the Advancement of Science]] stating that the letters gave "the impression of a search for some basis on which to discredit these particular scientists and findings, rather than a search for understanding", He stated that Mann, Bradley and Hughes had given out their full data and descriptions of methods.<ref name="beeb 18 July 2005">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sci/tech/4693855.stm |title=Science/Nature | Politics plays climate 'hockey' |author=Roland Pease |date=18 July 2005 |publisher=BBC News |quote= |accessdate=4 March 2011}}</ref><ref name="Leshner 13 July 2005">{{cite web|url=http://www.aaas.org/news/releases/2005/0714letter.pdf |title=www.aaas.org |author=Alan I. Leshner |authorlink=Alan I. Leshner |date=13 July 2005 |publisher=[[American Association for the Advancement of Science]] |quote= |accessdate=4 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110228070607/http://www.aaas.org/news/releases/2005/0714letter.pdf |archivedate=28 February 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref> A ''[[Washington Post]]'' editorial on 23 July which described the investigation as harassment quoted Bradley as saying it was "intrusive, far-reaching and intimidating", and Alan I. Leshner of the AAAS describing it as unprecedented in the 22 years he had been a government scientist; he thought it could "have a chilling effect on the willingness of people to work in areas that are politically relevant".<ref name="wapo Witches" /> Congressman Boehlert said the investigation was as "at best foolhardy" with the tone of the letters showing the committee's inexperience in relation to science.<ref name="beeb 18 July 2005" />
Barton was given support by global warming sceptic [[Myron Ebell]] of the [[Competitive Enterprise Institute]], who said "We've always wanted to get the science on trial ... we would like to figure out a way to get this into a court of law," and "this could work".<ref name="beeb 18 July 2005" /> In his ''Junk Science'' column on [[Fox News Channel|Fox News]], [[Steven Milloy]] said Barton's inquiry was reasonable.<ref name="Milloy FOXNews.com">{{cite news |url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,163999,00.html |title=Tree Ring Circus |author=Steven Milloy |authorlink=Steven Milloy |date=31 July 2005 |publisher=[[Fox News Channel|Fox News]] |quote= |accessdate=9 March 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110208112922/http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,163999,00.html |archive-date=8 February 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In September 2005 [[David Legates]] alleged in a newspaper op-ed that the issue showed climate scientists not abiding by data access requirements and suggested that legislators might ultimately take action to enforce them.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.senate.gov/comm/environment_and_public_works/general/repweeklycloser/TheWeeklyCloser9_23_05.pdf|title=The Weekly Closer from U.S. Senate, September 23, 2005.|format=PDF|accessdate=29 December 2008| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071128074617/https://www.senate.gov/comm/environment_and_public_works/general/repweeklycloser/TheWeeklyCloser9_23_05.pdf| archivedate = 28 November 2007}}</ref>
==Political questions== {{See also|Politics of global warming|Economics of global warming}}
[[File:H&WWonWashMon.png|right|thumb|The [[Washington Monument]] illuminated with a message from [[Greenpeace]] criticizing American environmental policy]]
In the U.S. global warming is often a partisan [[Politics of the United States|political issue]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.vox.com/2016/8/22/12590380/american-climate-politics |title=Watch the climate debate devolve into nonsense in the 10 years since An Inconvenient Truth |authors=Joss Fong and Joe Posner |date=August 23, 2016 |website=vox.com |publisher=[[Vox (website)|Vox]] |access-date=August 30, 2016 |quote=}}</ref> [[Republican Party (United States)|Republicans]] tend to oppose action against a threat that they regard as unproven, while [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrats]] tend to support actions that they believe will reduce global warming and its effects through the control of greenhouse gas emissions.<ref>{{cite web|title=GOP still cool on global warming|first=Lisa|last=Mascaro|newspaper=[[Las Vegas Sun]]|date=12 February 2007|url=http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2007/feb/12/gop-still-cool-on-global-warming/|accessdate=14 April 2007|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100102011923/http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2007/feb/12/gop-still-cool-on-global-warming/| archivedate=2 January 2010}}</ref> Climatologist [[Kevin E. Trenberth]] stated:
<blockquote>The SPM [Summary for policymakers] was approved line by line by governments[...] The argument here is that the scientists determine what can be said, but the governments determine how it can best be said. Negotiations occur over wording to ensure accuracy, balance, clarity of message, and relevance to understanding and policy. The IPCC process is dependent on the good will of the participants in producing a balanced assessment. However, in Shanghai, it appeared that there were attempts to blunt, and perhaps obfuscate, the messages in the report, most notably by Saudi Arabia. This led to very protracted debates over wording on even bland and what should be uncontroversial text... The most contentious paragraph in the IPCC (2001) SPM was the concluding one on attribution. After much debate, the following was carefully crafted: "In the light of new evidence, and taking into account the remaining uncertainties, most of the observed warming over the last 50 years is likely to have been due to the increase in greenhouse-gas concentrations."<ref>{{Cite journal|journal=Journal of the Forum for Environmental Law, Science, Engineering, and Finance|year=2001|issue=8–26|first=Kevin|last=Trenberth|authorlink=Kevin E. Trenberth|title=The IPCC Assessment of global warming 2001|url=http://www.cgd.ucar.edu/cas/GLOB_CHANGE/ipcc2001.html|format= [https://scholar.google.co.uk/scholar?hl=en&lr=&q=author%3ATrenberth+intitle%3AThe+IPCC+Assessment+of+global+warming+2001&as_publication=Journal+of+the+Forum+for+Environmental+Law%2C+Science%2C+Engineering%2C+and+Finance&as_ylo=2001&as_yhi=2001&btnG=Search Scholar search]| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061206221359/http://www.cgd.ucar.edu/cas/GLOB_CHANGE/ipcc2001.html| archivedate = 6 December 2006|ref=harv|accessdate=19 February 2014 |deadurl=yes}}</ref></blockquote>
As more evidence has become available over the existence of global warming debate has moved to further controversial issues{{Citation needed|date=March 2016}}, including:
# The social and environmental impacts # The appropriate response to climate change # Whether decisions require less uncertainty
The single largest issue is the importance of a few degrees rise in temperature: <blockquote>Most people say, "A few degrees? So what? If I change my thermostat a few degrees, I'll live fine." ... [The] point is that one or two degrees is about the experience that we have had in the last 10,000 years, the era of human civilization. There haven't been—globally averaged, we're talking—fluctuations of more than a degree or so. So we're actually getting into uncharted territory from the point of view of the relatively benign climate of the last 10,000 years, if we warm up more than a degree or two. ([[Stephen H. Schneider]]<ref>{{cite web|title=What's up with the weather: the debate: Stephen H. Schneider|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/warming/debate/schneider.html|publisher=[[PBS]] |work=[[Nova (TV series)|Nova]] ''and'' [[Frontline (U.S. TV series)|Frontline]]|accessdate=13 April 2007}}</ref>)</blockquote>
The other point that leads to major controversy—because it could have significant economic impacts—is whether action (usually, restrictions on the use of [[fossil fuel]]s to reduce carbon-dioxide emissions) should be taken now, or in the near future; and whether those restrictions would have any meaningful effect on global temperature.{{Citation needed|date=February 2007}}
Because of the economic ramifications of such restrictions, there are those, including the [[Cato Institute]], a [[Libertarianism|libertarian]] [[think tank]], who argue that the negative economic effects of emission controls outweigh the environmental benefits.<ref name="taylorspeech">{{cite web|url=http://www.cato.org/speeches/sp-jt011698.html|title=Global Warming, the Anatomy of a Debate: A speech by Jerry Taylor of the Cato Institute|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120124172640/http://www.cato.org/speeches/sp-jt011698.html |deadurl=yes|archivedate=24 January 2012}}</ref> They state that even if global warming is caused solely by the burning of fossil fuels, restricting their use would have more damaging effects on the world economy than the increases in global temperature.<ref name="PBSpalmer" />
<blockquote>The linkage between coal, electricity, and economic growth in the United States is as clear as it can be. And it is required for the way we live, the way we work, for our economic success, and for our future. Coal-fired electricity generation. It is necessary.(Fred Palmer, President of Western Fuels Association<ref name="PBSpalmer">{{cite web|title=What's up with the weather: the debate: Fred Palmer|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/warming/debate/palmer.html|publisher=[[PBS]] |work=[[Nova (TV series)|Nova]] ''and'' [[Frontline (U.S. TV series)|Frontline]]|accessdate=13 April 2007}}</ref>)</blockquote>
Conversely, others argue that early action to reduce emissions would help avoid much greater economic costs later, and would reduce the risk of catastrophic, irreversible change.<ref name="SternCh7">{{Cite book|title=Stern Review: The Economics of Climate Change |chapter=7. Projecting the Growth of Greenhouse-Gas Emissions |chapterurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061209034440/http://www.hm-treasury.gov.uk/media/3F8/81/ch_7_projecting_growth_of_ghg_emissions.pdf |publisher=[[HM Treasury]], [[Cambridge University Press]] |editor1-first=Nicolas |editor1-last=Stern |editor1-link=Nicholas Stern |isbn=978-0-521-70080-1 |url=http://www.hm-treasury.gov.uk/independent_reviews/stern_review_economics_climate_change/stern_review_report.cfm |year=2006 |author=Nicholas Stern |format=– <sup>[https://scholar.google.co.uk/scholar?hl=en&lr=&q=intitle%3AStern+Review%3A+The+Economics+of+Climate+Change&as_publication=&as_ylo=2006&as_yhi=2006&btnG=Search Scholar search]</sup> |accessdate=19 February 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071024003134/http://www.hm-treasury.gov.uk/independent_reviews/stern_review_economics_climate_change/stern_review_report.cfm |archivedate=24 October 2007 |df= }}</ref> In his December 2006 book, ''[[Hell and High Water (book)|Hell and High Water]]'', [[Joseph J. Romm]] <blockquote>discusses the urgency to act and the sad fact that America is refusing to do so...</blockquote>
On a local or regional level, some specific [[benefits of global warming|effects of global warming might be considered beneficial]].<ref name="Washington Post">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/health-science/global-warming-would-harm-the-earth-but-some-areas-might-find-it-beneficial/2012/01/17/gIQAbXwhLQ_story.html |title=Global warming would harm the Earth, but some areas might find it beneficial | work=The Washington Post | first=Brian|last=Palmer|date=30 January 2012}}</ref>
[[Council on Foreign Relations]] senior fellow [[Walter Russell Mead]] argues that the 2009 [[Copenhagen Summit]] failed because environmentalists have changed from "Bambi to Godzilla". According to Mead, environmentalist used to represent the skeptical few who made valid arguments against big government programs which tried to impose simple but massive solutions on complex situations. Environmentalists' more recent advocacy for big economic and social intervention against global warming, according to Mead, has made them, "the voice of the establishment, of the tenured, of the technocrats" and thus has lost them the support of a public which is increasingly skeptical of global warming.<ref>[[George Will|Will, George]], "[http://www.denverpost.com/opinion/ci_15978060 When Bambi becomes Godzilla] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100909234738/http://www.denverpost.com/opinion/ci_15978060 |date=9 September 2010 }}", ''[[The Denver Post]]'', 5 September 2010.</ref>
Various campaigns such as [[350.org]] and many [[Greenpeace]] projects have been started in an effort to push the world's leaders towards changing laws and policies that would effectively reduce the world's carbon emissions and use of non-renewable energy resources.{{Citation needed|date=March 2016}}
=== Kyoto Protocol === {{Main|Kyoto Protocol}}
The Kyoto Protocol is the most prominent international agreement on climate change, and is also highly controversial. Some argue that it goes too far<ref>{{cite web|title=A Guide to Kyoto: Climate Change and What it Means to Canadians: Does the Kyoto treaty go far enough... or too far?|first=Ian|last=Darragh|publisher=[[International Institute for Sustainable Development]]|year=1998|url=http://www.iisd.org/pdf/kyotoprimer_en.pdf|accessdate=14 April 2007|format=PDF}}</ref> or not nearly far enough<ref>{{cite web|url=http://unfccc.int/files/essential_background/kyoto_protocol/application/pdf/kpstats.pdf|publisher=UNFCCC|title=Kyoto protocol status|accessdate=7 November 2006|format=PDF}} ([[Niue]],The [[Cook Islands]], [[Nauru]] consider reductions "inadequate")</ref> in restricting emissions of greenhouse gases. Another area of controversy is the fact that China and India, the world's two most populous countries, both ratified the protocol but are not required to reduce or even limit the growth of carbon emissions under the present agreement even though when [[List of countries by greenhouse gas emissions per capita|listed by greenhouse gas emissions per capita]], they have rankings of 121st largest per capita emitter at 3.9 Tonnes of [[Carbon dioxide equivalent|{{CO2}}e]] and 162nd largest per capita emitter at 1.8 Tonnes of [[Carbon dioxide equivalent|{{CO2}}e]] respectively, compared with for example the U.S. at position of the 14th largest per capita [[Carbon dioxide equivalent|{{CO2}}e]] emitter at 22.9 Tonnes of [[Carbon dioxide equivalent|{{CO2}}e]]. Nevertheless, China is the world's second largest producer of greenhouse gas emissions, and India 4th (see: [[List of countries by carbon dioxide emissions|countries by greenhouse emissions]]). Various predictions see China overtaking the US in total greenhouse emissions between late 2007 and 2010,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn11707-chinas-emissions-to-surpass-the-us-within-months.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070427040854/http://environment.newscientist.com/article/dn11707-chinas-emissions-to-surpass-the-us-within-months.html |archivedate=27 April 2007|title=China's emissions may surpass the US in 2007|author=Catherine Brahic|date=25 April 2007|newspaper=[[New Scientist]]|accessdate=20 May 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.independent.co.uk/world/asia/article1962439.ece|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930185653/http://news.independent.co.uk/world/asia/article1962439.ece |archivedate=30 September 2007|author=Saeed Shah|title=China to pass US greenhouse gas levels by 2010|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|date=8 November 2006|accessdate=20 May 2007 | location=London}} </ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/PEK78904.htm|agency=Reuters |publisher=[[AlertNet]]|title=China fears disasters, grain cut from global warming|date=27 December 2006|accessdate=20 May 2007}}</ref> and according to many other estimates, this already occurred in 2006.<ref name="ChinaNo1">[https://web.archive.org/web/20070521085142/http://www.mnp.nl/en/dossiers/Climatechange/moreinfo/Chinanowno1inCO2emissionsUSAinsecondposition.html China now no. 1 in {{CO2}} emissions; US in second position] [[Netherlands Environmental Assessment Agency]]. Retrieved 20 June 2007.</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://environment.guardian.co.uk/climatechange/story/0,,2106689,00.html |title=China overtakes US as world's biggest {{Co2}} emitter |newspaper=The Guardian |date=19 June 2007|accessdate=9 February 2010 |last=Vidal |first=John |last2=Adam |first2=David | location=London}} <!-- http://www.energybulletin.net/31156.html EnergyBulletin.net|Peak Oil News Clearinghouse --></ref>
Additionally, high costs of decreasing emissions may cause significant production to move to countries that are not covered under the treaty, such as India and China, says [[Fred Singer]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Climate Policy – From Rio to Kyoto: A Political Issue for 2000—and Beyond|location=[[Stanford University]]|series=Essays in Public Policy, No. 102|publisher=[[Hoover Institution]]|first=S. Fred|last=Singer|authorlink=S. Fred Singer|date=24 May 2000|accessdate=13 April 2007|isbn=978-0-8179-4372-1|page=49|url=http://www.hoover.org/publications/epp/2834741.html?show=summary|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929083942/http://www.hoover.org/publications/epp/2834741.html?show=summary|archivedate=29 September 2007|df=dmy-all}}</ref> As these countries are less energy efficient, this scenario is said {{By whom|date=March 2016}}to cause additional carbon emissions.{{Citation needed|date=March 2016}}
In May 2010 [[the Hartwell Paper]] was published by the [[London School of Economics]] in collaboration with the [[University of Oxford]].<ref name=Hartwell>{{cite web|url=http://eprints.lse.ac.uk/27939/1/HartwellPaper_English_version.pdf|title=The Hartwell Paper – A new direction for climate policy after the crash of 2009|author=Prins, Gwyn et. al |publisher=[[London School of Economics]] |date=May 2010|accessdate=12 May 2010}}</ref> This paper was written by 14 academics from various disciplines in the sciences and humanities, and also some policies thinkers, and they argued that the [[Kyoto Protocol]] crashed in late 2009 and "has failed to produce any discernable real world reductions in emissions of greenhouse gases in fifteen years."<ref name=Hartwell/> They argued that this failure opened an opportunity to set climate policy free from Kyoto and the paper advocates a controversial and piecemeal approach to [[Low-carbon economy|decarbonization]] of the global economy.<ref name=Economist0510/><ref name=Science0510/> The Hartwell paper proposes, "the organising principle of our effort should be the raising up of human dignity via three overarching objectives: ensuring energy access for all; ensuring that we develop in a manner that does not undermine the essential functioning of the Earth system; ensuring that our societies are adequately equipped to withstand the risks and dangers that come from all the vagaries of climate, whatever their cause may be".<ref name=Hartwell/><ref name=Economist0510>{{cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/world/international/displaystory.cfm?story_id=16099521|title=Oblique strategies|work=The Economist|date=11 May 2010|accessdate=12 May 2010}}</ref><ref name=Science0510>{{cite news|url=http://news.sciencemag.org/scienceinsider/2010/05/do-you-heart-the-hartwell-paper.html|title=Do You Heart 'The Hartwell Paper'?|publisher=[[Science (journal)|Science Insider]]|date=12 May 2010|accessdate=12 May 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100528030007/http://news.sciencemag.org/scienceinsider/2010/05/do-you-heart-the-hartwell-paper.html|archivedate=28 May 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
The only major developed nation which has signed but not ratified the Kyoto protocol is the US ([[list of Kyoto Protocol signatories|see signatories]]). The countries with no official position on Kyoto are mainly African countries with underdeveloped scientific infrastructure or are oil producers {{Citation needed|date=August 2007}}.
=== Funding === {{See also|Climate change denial}} The [[Global Climate Coalition]] was an industry coalition that funded several scientists who expressed skepticism about global warming. In the year 2000, several members left the coalition when they became the target of a national divestiture campaign run by [[John Passacantando]] and [[Phil Radford]] at Ozone Action. According to ''[[The New York Times]]'', when Ford Motor Company was the first company to leave the coalition, it was "the latest sign of divisions within heavy industry over how to respond to global warming".<ref name="Canvassing Works">{{cite web |publisher=[[Canvassing Works]] |url= http://www.canvassingworks.org/canvassingworks/2006/09/alumni_update_p.html |title= Canvassing Works |accessdate=19 July 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.nytimes.com/1999/12/07/business/ford-announces-its-withdrawal-from-global-climate-coalition.html |title=Ford Announces Its Withdrawal From Global Climate Coalition |newspaper=The New York Times|accessdate=21 July 2013|first=Keith|last=Bradsher|date=7 December 1999}}</ref> After that, between December, 1999 and early March, 2000, the GCC was deserted by Daimler-Chrysler, Texaco, energy firm the [[Southern Company]] and General Motors.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.heatisonline.org/contentserver/objecthandlers/index.cfm?id=3440&method=full|title= GCC Suffers Technical Knockout, Industry defections decimate Global Climate Coalition }}</ref> The [[Global Climate Coalition]] closed in 2002, or in their own words, 'deactivated'.<ref name="org">{{cite web|url=http://globalclimate.org/ |title=globalclimate.org|publisher=Global Climate |date=19 April 2003 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20030419031622/http://globalclimate.org/ |archivedate = 19 April 2003}}</ref>
Documents obtained by [[Greenpeace]] under the US [[Freedom of Information Act (United States)|Freedom of Information Act]] show that the [[Koch Family Foundations|Charles G. Koch Foundation]] gave climate change writer [[Willie Soon]] two grants totaling $175,000 in 2005/6 and again in 2010. Multiple grants to Soon from the [[American Petroleum Institute]] between 2001 and 2007, totalled $274,000, and from [[ExxonMobil]] totalled $335,000 between 2005 and 2010. Other coal and oil industry sources which funded him include the Mobil Foundation, the Texaco Foundation and the [[Electric Power Research Institute]]. Soon, acknowledging that he received this money, stated unequivocally that he has "never been motivated by financial reward in any of my scientific research".<ref name=Vidal>{{cite news|first=John |last=Vidal |title=Climate sceptic Willie Soon received $1m from oil companies, papers show | newspaper = The Guardian | date = 27 June 2011 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2011/jun/28/climate-change-sceptic-willie-soon| location=London}}</ref> In February 2015, Greenpeace disclosed papers documenting that Soon failed to disclose to academic journals funding including more than $1.2 million from fossil fuel industry related interests including ExxonMobil, the American Petroleum Institute, the [[Koch family foundations#Charles G. Koch Charitable Foundation|Charles G. Koch Charitable Foundation]] and the Southern Company.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn27028-climate-change-sceptics-work-called-into-question.html |title=Climate change sceptic's work called into question |date=February 25, 2015 |work=[[New Scientist]] |accessdate=March 17, 2015 |first=Catherine |last=Brahic}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2015/02/23/the-favorite-scientist-of-climate-change-deniers-is-under-fire-for-taking-oil-money/ |title=Things just got very hot for climate deniers’ favorite scientist |date=February 23, 2015 |newspaper=[[Washington Post]] |accessdate=March 17, 2015 |first=Terrence |last=McCoy}}</ref><ref name="deeper">{{cite news |first1=Justin |last1=Gillis |first2=John |last2=Schwartz |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/22/us/ties-to-corporate-cash-for-climate-change-researcher-Wei-Hock-Soon.html |title= Deeper Ties to Corporate Cash for Doubtful Climate Researcher |date=February 21, 2015 |accessdate=2015-02-21 |newspaper=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref> To investigate how widespread such hidden funding was, senators [[Barbara Boxer]], [[Edward Markey]] and [[Sheldon Whitehouse]] wrote to a number of companies. Koch general counsel refused the request and said it would infringe the company's first amendment rights.<ref name="Yuhas 20150313">{{Cite news | last=Yuhas | first=Alan | title=Koch Industries refuses to comply with US senators' climate investigation | newspaper=The Guardian | date=13 Mar 2015 | url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2015/mar/13/koch-industries-refuses-senators-climate-investigation | accessdate=17 Apr 2015}}</ref>
The [[Greenpeace]] research project ExxonSecrets, and [[George Monbiot]] writing in ''[[The Guardian]]'', as well as various academics,<ref name="merchants of doubt">{{cite book |title=Merchants of Doubt: How a Handful of Scientists Obscured the Truth on Issues from Tobacco Smoke to Global Warming |author=Naomi Oreskes |author2=Erik Conway |isbn=978-1-59691-610-4 |year=2010 |publisher=Bloomsbury |location=US|title-link=Merchants of Doubt }}</ref><ref name="requiem">{{cite book |title=Requiem for a Species: Why We Resist the Truth about Climate Change |pages=103–105 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YRkkifKboIYC&pg=105 |author=Clive Hamilton |isbn=978-1-74237-210-5 |year=2010 |publisher=Allen & Unwin |accessdate=19 February 2014}}</ref> have linked several skeptical scientists—[[Fred Singer]], [[Fred Seitz]] and [[Patrick Michaels]]—to organizations funded by [[ExxonMobil]] and [[Philip Morris USA|Philip Morris]] for the purpose of promoting global warming skepticism. These organizations include the [[Cato Institute]] and [[the Heritage Foundation]].<ref name="monbiot06">{{cite news|title=The denial industry|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2006/sep/19/ethicalliving.g2|accessdate=11 August 2007|publisher=The Guardian|quote="By May 1993, as another memo from APCO to Philip Morris shows, the fake citizens' group had a name: the Advancement of Sound Science Coalition." | location=London | first=George | last=Monbiot | date=19 September 2006}}</ref> Similarly, groups employing global warming skeptics, such as the [[George C. Marshall Institute]], have been criticized for their ties to fossil fuel companies.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/life/science/story/0,12996,1399585,00.html|first=David|last=Adam|newspaper=The Guardian|title=Oil firms fund climate change 'denial'|date=27 January 2005|accessdate=14 April 2007 | location=London}}</ref>
On 2 February 2007, ''The Guardian'' stated<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/frontpage/story/0,,2004399,00.html|first=Ian|last=Sample|newspaper=The Guardian|title=Scientists offered cash to dispute climate study|date=2 February 2007|accessdate=14 April 2007 | location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aei.org/publications/pubID.25586,filter.all/pub_detail.asp |title=Climate Controversy and AEI: Facts and Fictions |publisher=[[American Enterprise Institute]] for Public Policy Research |date=9 February 2007 |accessdate=14 April 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070413224426/http://www.aei.org/publications/pubID.25586%2Cfilter.all/pub_detail.asp |archivedate=13 April 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> that Kenneth Green, a Visiting Scholar with [[American Enterprise Institute|AEI]], had sent letters<ref>{{cite web|url=http://websrvr80il.audiovideoweb.com/il80web20037/ThinkProgress/2007/aeiletter.pdf|title=AEI Letter to Pf. Schroeder|date=5 July 2006|first=Steven F.|last=Hayward|author2=Kenneth Green|accessdate=14 April 2007|format=PDF| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070208101842/http://websrvr80il.audiovideoweb.com/il80web20037/ThinkProgress/2007/aeiletter.pdf| archivedate = 8 February 2007}}</ref> to scientists in the UK and the U.S., offering US$10,000 plus travel expenses and other incidental payments in return for essays with the purpose of "highlight[ing] the strengths and weaknesses of the IPCC process", specifically regarding the [[IPCC Fourth Assessment Report]].{{Citation needed|date=March 2016}}
A furor was raised when it was revealed that the [[Intermountain Rural Electric Association]] (an energy cooperative that draws a significant portion of its electricity from [[coal-burning power plant]]s) donated $100,000 to Patrick Michaels and his group, [[New Hope Environmental Services]], and solicited additional private donations from its members.<ref>[http://abcnews.go.com/Technology/GlobalWarming/story?id=2242565&page=1 ABC News Reporting Cited As Evidence In Congressional Hearing On Global Warming] ABC August 2006</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://achangeinthewind.typepad.com/achangeinthewind/files/lewandowski_memo.pdf|title=Lewandowski memo|format=PDF|accessdate=29 December 2008}}</ref>{{Unreliable source?|date=July 2010}}<ref>[http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/N01433004.htm FEATURE-Carbon backlash: coal divides corporations] James, Steve Reuters, July 2007</ref>
The [[Union of Concerned Scientists]] produced a report titled 'Smoke, Mirrors & Hot Air',<ref name="autogenerated2">{{cite web|title=Smoke, Mirrors & Hot Air – How ExxonMobil Uses Big Tobacco's Tactics to Manufacture Uncertainty on Climate Science|publisher=[[Union of Concerned Scientists]]|date=January 2007|url=http://www.ucsusa.org/global_warming/science/exxonmobil-smoke-mirrors-hot.html|accessdate=14 April 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070410184455/http://www.ucsusa.org/global_warming/science/exxonmobil-smoke-mirrors-hot.html|archivedate=10 April 2007|df=dmy-all}}</ref> that criticizes ExxonMobil for "[[underwriting]] the most sophisticated and most successful disinformation campaign since the tobacco industry" and for "[[funnelling]] about $16 million between 1998 and 2005 to a network of ideological and advocacy organizations that manufacture uncertainty on the issue". In 2006, Exxon said that it was no longer going to fund these groups<ref>[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/16593606/ Exxon cuts ties to global warming skeptics] MSNBC January 2007</ref> though that statement has been challenged by Greenpeace.<ref>[http://www.greenpeace.org/usa/news/exxonsecrets-2007 Exxon Still Funding Climate Change Deniers] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070819134355/http://www.greenpeace.org/usa/news/exxonsecrets-2007 |date=19 August 2007 }} Greenpeace May 2007</ref>
The [[Center for the Study of Carbon Dioxide and Global Change]], a skeptic group, when confronted about the funding of a video they put together ($250,000 for "[[The Greening of Planet Earth]]" from an oil company) stated, "We applaud Western Fuels for their willingness to publicize a side of the story that we believe to be far more correct than what at one time was 'generally accepted'. But does this mean that they fund The Center? Maybe it means that we fund them!"<ref>{{cite web|title=Links|url=http://www.westernfuels.org/links.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060115152729/http://www.westernfuels.org/links.htm |archivedate=15 January 2006|accessdate=13 April 2007|publisher=Western Fuels}}</ref>
[[Donald Kennedy]], editor-in-chief of ''[[Science (journal)|Science]]'', has said that skeptics such as Michaels are lobbyists more than researchers, and "I don't think it's unethical any more than most lobbying is unethical," he said. He said donations to skeptics amounts to "trying to get a political message across".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2006/07/27/ap/tech/mainD8J4GH300.shtml|title=Utilities Paying Global Warming Skeptic|first=Seth|last=Borenstein|publisher=[[CBS News]] from [[Associated Press]]|date=27 July 2006|accessdate=14 April 2007| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070303080433/http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2006/07/27/ap/tech/mainD8J4GH300.shtml| archivedate = 3 March 2007}}</ref>
Global warming skeptic [[Reid Bryson]] said in June 2007, "There is a lot of money to be made in this... If you want to be an eminent scientist you have to have a lot of grad students and a lot of grants. You can't get grants unless you say, 'Oh global warming, yes, yes, carbon dioxide'."<ref>Real Clear Politics: [http://www.realclearpolitics.com/articles/2007/06/hooey_denier_deniers.html Hooey Denier Deniers.] 24 June 2007.</ref> Similar positions have been advanced by [[University of Alabama, Huntsville]] climate scientist [[Roy Spencer (scientist)|Roy Spencer]], Spencer's University of Alabama, Huntsville colleague and IPCC contributor [[John Christy]], University of London biogeographer [[Philip Stott]],<ref>{{cite news|title=Must-See Global Warming TV|publisher=[[Fox News]]|date=March 2007|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,258993,00.html|accessdate=14 May 2007|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070517143252/http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,258993,00.html|archive-date=17 May 2007|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> [[Accuracy in Media]],<ref>Trulock, Notra, [http://www.aim.org/publications/aim_report/2002/15.html "Science for Sale: the Global Warming Scam"] Accuracy in Media, 26 August 2002</ref> and [[Ian Plimer]] in his 2009 book ''[[Heaven and Earth (book)|Heaven and Earth — Global Warming: The Missing Science]]''.{{Citation needed|date=March 2016}}<ref>{{Cite book|title=Heaven and Earth:Global Warming, the Missing Science|last=Plimer|first=Ian|publisher=Connor Court Publication|year=2009|isbn=|location=Australia|pages=}}</ref>
[[Richard Lindzen]], the [[Alfred P. Sloan]] Professor of [[Meteorology]] at [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology|MIT]], said, "[in] the winter of 1989 Reginald Newell, a professor of meteorology [at MIT], lost [[National Science Foundation]] funding for data analyses that were failing to show net warming over the past century." Lindzen also suggested that four other scientists "apparently" lost their funding or positions after questioning the scientific underpinnings of global warming.<ref>{{cite web|title=Climate of Fear|publisher=OpinionJournal.com |date=April 2006|url=http://www.opinionjournal.com/extra/?id=110008220|accessdate=14 May 2007}}</ref> Lindzen himself has been the recipient of money from energy interests such as [[OPEC]] and the [[Western Fuels Association]], including "$2,500 a day for his consulting services",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dieoff.org/page82.htm|title=The Heat Is On: The warming of the world's climate sparks a blaze of denial|first=Ross|last=Gelbspan|authorlink=Ross Gelbspan|work=[[Harper's Magazine]]|date=December 1995|accessdate=8 February 2008}}</ref> as well as funding from US federal sources including the National Science Foundation, the [[United States Department of Energy|Department of Energy]], and [[NASA]].<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www-eaps.mit.edu/faculty/lindzen/203_2001GL014074.pdf|title=Reconciling observations of global temperature change|last=Lindzen|first=Richard S.|authorlink=Richard Lindzen|author2=Constantine Giannitsis|year=2002|journal=Geophysical Research Letters|volume=29|issue=12|pages=24{{hyphen}}1–24{{hyphen}}3|accessdate=10 September 2007|format=PDF|doi=10.1029/2001GL014074|bibcode=2002GeoRL..29.1583L|ref=harv}}</ref><!-- See acknowledgments on last page -->
=== Debate over most effective response to warming === {{See also|list of scientists opposing the mainstream scientific assessment of global warming}}
In recent years some skeptics have changed their positions regarding global warming. [[Ronald Bailey]], author of ''Global Warming and Other Eco-Myths'' (published by the [[Competitive Enterprise Institute]] in 2002), stated in 2005, "Anyone still holding onto the idea that there is no global warming ought to hang it up."<ref> {{cite news |url= http://www.reason.com/links/links081105.shtml |title= We're All Global Warmers Now |date= 11 August 2005 |author= Ronald Bailey |publisher= [[Reason (magazine)|Reason Online]] |accessdate=27 April 2008 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061024205457/http://www.reason.com/links/links081105.shtml|archivedate=24 October 2006 |deadurl= yes }}</ref> By 2007, he wrote "Details like sea level rise will continue to be debated by researchers, but if the debate over whether or not humanity is contributing to global warming wasn't over before, it is now.... as the new IPCC Summary makes clear, climate change [[Pollyanna principle|Pollyannaism]] is no longer looking very tenable."<ref> {{cite web |first= Ronald |last= Bailey |authorlink= Ronald Bailey |title= Global Warming—Not Worse Than We Thought, But Bad Enough |url= http://www.reason.com/news/show/118479.html |work= [[Reason (magazine)|Reason]] |date= 2 February 2007 |accessdate=13 April 2007 }}</ref>
"There are alternatives to its [the climate-change crusade's] insistence that the only appropriate policy response is steep and immediate emissions reductions.... a greenhouse-gas-emissions cap ultimately would constrain energy production. A sensible climate policy would emphasize building resilience into our capacity to adapt to climate changes.... we should consider strategies of adaptation to a changing climate. A rise in the sea level need not be the end of the world, as the Dutch have taught us." says Steven F.
