{{Infobox project | name = The Ice Stupa project | logo = | image =Ice stupas near Phyang monastery DSCN7587 1.jpg | caption = Ice stupas near [[Phyang Monastery]] in February 2018 | mission_statement = | commercial = No | type = [[Water conservation]] | products = | location = [[Ladakh]], India | country = [[India]] | owner = [[Students' Educational and Cultural Movement of Ladakh]] (SECMOL) | founder = [[Sonam Wangchuk (Engineer)|Sonam Wangchuk]] | key_people = Sonam Wangchuk | established = {{Start date and age|2013|10|df=y}} | disestablished = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | funding = [[Crowdfunding]] | budget = {{INRConvert|7500000}} | current_status = Operational | website = {{URL|http://icestupa.org/}} }} '''Ice Stupa''' is a form of [[Glacier growing|glacier grafting]] technique that creates artificial [[glacier]]s, used for storing winter water (which otherwise would go unused) in the form of conical shaped ice heaps. During summer, when water is scarce, the Ice Stupa melts to increase water supply for crops. Ice Stupa was invented by [[Sonam Wangchuk (Engineer)|Sonam Wangchuk]] in [[Ladakh]] (India) and the project is undertaken by the [[Non-governmental organization|NGO]] [[Students' Educational and Cultural Movement of Ladakh]]. Launched in October 2013, the test project started in January 2014 under the project name ''The Ice Stupa project''. On 15 November 2016, Sonam Wangchuk was awarded the [[Rolex Awards for Enterprise]] for his work on Ice Stupa. [[File:Aerial view of Ice stupa and Phyang monastery from flight IMG 2411 1.jpg|thumb|Aerial view of Ice stupa and Phyang monastery from flight ]] ==Background== Ladakh is a [[cold desert]] and during winter [[agriculture]] is not practiced due to frozen soil and low air temperatures. During [[Spring (season)|spring season]], water requirement for [[sowing]] increases whereas [[stream]]s dry up. With annual rainfall of less than {{convert|50|mm|in}}, agriculture in Ladakh is solely dependent on snow and glacier [[meltwater]]. Due to [[climate change]], the region experiences hotter summers with increase in melts along with shift in the timing and precipitation of the melts. Subsequently, during the spring season water is more scarce which in turn impacts agriculture and food supplies.<ref name="Ice Stupas: Conserving water the 3 Idiots way">{{cite news|title=Ice Stupas: Conserving water the 3 Idiots way|publisher=[[Forbes India]]|accessdate=21 November 2016|url=http://www.forbesindia.com/article/checkin/ice-stupas-conserving-water-the-3-idiots-way/39265/1}}</ref><ref name="Sonam Wangchuk Wins the Rolex Award ">{{cite news|title=Sonam Wangchuk Wins the Rolex Award |publisher=thewire.in/|accessdate=21 November 2016|url=http://thewire.in/81327/wangchuk-rolex-stupa-secmol/}}</ref><ref name="Ice Stupas: Water conservation in the land of the Buddha">{{cite news|title=Ice Stupas: Water conservation in the land of the Buddha|publisher=indiawaterportal.org|accessdate=21 November 2016|url=http://www.indiawaterportal.org/articles/ice-stupas-water-conservation-land-buddha}}</ref>
In the month of May, Sonam Wangchuk noticed the ice under a bridge. Despite summer and lowest elevation in Ladakh, the ice had not melted since it was not under direct sunlight. Wangchuk realized ice could last longer in Ladakh if it could be shaded from the sun. Since providing shade to larger water bodies was not possible, Wangchuk thought of freezing and storing water in the shape of a cone that offers minimum surface area to the sun whilst holding high volume of water.<ref name="Sonam Wangchuk Wins the Rolex Award"/>
In October 2013, Sonam Wangchuk created the first [[prototype]] of {{convert|6|m|ft|0}} Ice Stupa by freezing {{cvt|150000|l|gal}} in [[Leh]] without any shade from the sun. Water was piped from upstream using gravity. Electricity or machinery was not used for pumping water. The Ice Stupa did not melt fully till 18 May 2014, even when the temperature was above {{convert|20|C}}.<ref name="Ice Stupas: Conserving water the 3 Idiots way"/><ref name="Sonam Wangchuk Wins the Rolex Award "/><ref name="Ice Stupas: Water conservation in the land of the Buddha"/><ref name="Ice Stupa - A Form of Artificial Glacier">{{cite news|title=Ice Stupa - A Form of Artificial Glacier|publisher=Official website|accessdate=21 November 2016|url=http://icestupa.org/}}</ref>

{{COI|date=December 2017}} Established in September 2005, the '''Institute for Governance of Private and Public Organizations''' (IGOPP) is a Canadian think tank and joint initiative of [[HEC Montréal]] and [[Concordia University]] (The [[John Molson School of Business]]) and the Jarislowsky Foundation. The Institute is committed to promoting strong corporate governance practices among organizations in [[Quebec]] and the rest of Canada.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://igopp.org/en |title=Institute for governance of private and public organizations |author=''IGOPP'' |accessdate=February 2015}}</ref>
== Activity == Its operations focus primarily on key management activities, namely defining the corporate mission, evaluating strategic management and financial performance, recruiting and compensating officers and managing risk. It achieves this through: * [https://igopp.org/en/category/policy-papers/ Policy papers]: The Institute supports academic research, takes part in public debates on governance issues, reinforces governance related skills; * [https://igopp.org/en/category/publications-en/reports-studies/ Research]: the aim is to stimulate debate on key issues of governance by providing rigorous research work; * [https://igopp.org/en/category/courses-and-events/upcoming-events/ Training]: IGOPP organizes conferences and training seminars * [https://igopp.org/en/category/publications-en/articles-news/ Dissemination of information]: The Institute promotes partnership and knowledge transfer.
== Policy papers == From 2006 to 2017, nine policy papers have been prepared on topical issues:
* [https://igopp.org/en/executive-compensation-cutting-the-gordian-knot/ Executive compensation: Cutting the Gordian knot] * [https://igopp.org/en/who-should-pick-board-members/ Who should pick board members?] * [https://igopp.org/en/the-troubling-case-of-proxy-advisors/ The Troubling Case of Proxy Advisors] Some policy recommendations * [https://igopp.org/en/pay-for-value/ Executive compensation] Pay for value: Cutting the Gordian Knot of Executive Compensation * [https://igopp.org/en/giving-shareholders-a-say-on-pay/ Giving Shareholders a Say on Pay] A measure leading to better governance? * [https://igopp.org/en/the-status-of-women-corporate-directors-in-canada/ The Status of Women Corporate Directors in Canada] Pushing for Change * [https://igopp.org/en/the-independence-of-board-members/ The Independence of Board Members]: A Quest for Legitimacy * [https://igopp.org/en/corporate-citizenship-and-the-right-to-vote/ Corporate citizenship and the right to vote] A proposal * [https://igopp.org/en/dual-class-share-structures-in-canada/ Dual-class share structures in Canada] Review and recommendations
== Books == Yvan Allaire <ref>{{Cite web |url=http://igopp.org/en/igopp/board-of-directors/yvan-allaire-phd-mit-frsc/ |title=Yvan Allaire |accessdate=February 2015}}</ref> and IGOPP's books deal with the financial market, mining royalties, [[executive compensation]], "good governance" in the public or private sector, takeovers of listed companies, regulation of financial markets, Davos, the presence of women on boards and many other themes relevant to governance. These books are constantly looking to provide a measured opinion, sensitive to others', by formulating policy proposals that respect the rights of the parties. Their authors' are always concerned about the perverse and unexpected effects of good intentions. * [https://igopp.org/en/on-becoming-an-activist-board-in-the-age-of-activist-shareholders/ On becoming an ''activist board''... In the age of activist shareholders] * [https://igopp.org/en/a-capitalism-of-owners/ A Capitalism of Owners : How Financial Markets Destroy Companies and Societies and What to Do About It] <ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/careers/management/corporate-leaders-suffer-under-the-capitalist-gun/article4253378/ |title=Corporate leaders suffer under the capitalist gun |author='' Harvey Schachter '' |date=June 2012 |editor=''The Globe and Mail'' |accessdate=February 2015}}</ref> * [https://igopp.org/en/black-markets-and-business-blues-2/ Black Markets and Business Blues : The Man-Made Crisis of 2007-2009 and the Road to a New Capitalism]. Silver medal, Category : Current Events I (Political/Economic/Legal/Media) of the 2010 Independent Publisher Book Awards.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.independentpublisher.com/article.php?page=1362 |title=Independent Publisher |author=''Independent Publisher'' |date=June 2010 |accessdate= February 2015}}</ref> * [https://igopp.org/en/beyond-monks-and-minow/ Beyond Monks and Minow: From Fiduciary to Value Creating Governance]
== Reports and studies == * [https://igopp.org/en/are-our-state-owned-enterprises-well-governed/ Are our State-owned enterprises well governed?] * [https://igopp.org/en/cp-rail-a-case-of-successful-activism/ Pershing Square, Ackman and CP Rail: A Case of Successful ''Activism''?] * [https://igopp.org/en/corporate-governance-looking-backward-forward/ Corporate Governance: looking backward, looking forward] * [https://igopp.org/en/les-sieges-sociaux-des-grandes-entreprises-du-quebec-sont-ils-en-peril/ What's the risk of losing a significant number of corporate head offices now located in Quebec?] * [https://igopp.org/en/enhancing-the-dynamics-of-boards-of-directors/ Enhancing the dynamics of board of directors: An exchange with experienced board members] * [https://igopp.org/en/two-flawed-studies-about-controlled-corporations-by-iss-and-irrci/ Two flawed studies about controlled corporations by ISS and IRRCI] * [https://igopp.org/en/the-game-of-activist-hedge-funds-cui-bono/ The game of ''activist'' hedge funds: Cui bono?] * [https://igopp.org/en/still-unanswered-questions-and-new-ones-to-bebchuk-brav-and-jiang/ Still unanswered questions (and new ones) to Bebchuk, Brav and Jiang]: This paper is the third one of a series of three papers on [Hedge Fund] Activism. * [https://igopp.org/en/the-case-for-and-against-activist-hedge-funds-2/ "The case for and against activist hedge funds"] * [https://igopp.org/en/iss-the-value-of-just-say-no/ The value of "just say no": A Response to ISS] * [https://igopp.org/en/to-govern-in-the-interest-of-the-corporation-what-is-the-boards-responsibility-to-stakeholders-other-than-shareholders/ To govern in the interest of the corporation] : What is the board’s responsibility to [[stakeholder (corporate)|stakeholder]]s other than shareholder? * [https://igopp.org/en/hedge-fund-activism-and-their-long-term-consequences-unanswered-questions-to-bebchuk-brav-and-jiang/ Hedge Fund Activism and their Long-Term Consequences Unanswered Questions to Bebchuk, Brav and Jiang] * [https://igopp.org/en/board-members-compensation-and-governance-issues-and-challenges/ Board Members' Compensation and Governance: Issues and Challenges] * [https://igopp.org/en/the-governance-of-canadian-airports-issues-and-recommendations/ The Governance of Canadian Airports; Issues and Recommendations] * [https://igopp.org/en/on-becoming-an-activist-board/ On becoming an activist board! Sketch of a corporate governance that creates value] * [https://igopp.org/en/activist-hedge-funds-creators-of-lasting-wealth-what-do-the-_-empirical-studies-really-say/ "Activist" hedge funds: creators of lasting wealth? What do the _ empirical studies really say?]<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://blogs.law.harvard.edu/corpgov/2014/07/22/do-activist-hedge-funds-really-create-long-term-value/ |title=Do Activist Hedge Funds Really Create Long Term Value? |author=''Martin Lipton'' |date= July 2014 |editor=''Harvard Law School Forum on Corporate Governance and Financial Regulation'' |accessdate = February 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150209225440/http://blogs.law.harvard.edu/corpgov/2014/07/22/do-activist-hedge-funds-really-create-long-term-value/ |archivedate=2015-02-09 }}</ref>
== Members of the board of directors == Chaired by Dr. Yvan Allaire, a well-known figure in the business world, the [[board of directors]] of the institute is made up of 15 prominent individuals from various field: senior executives of big and small businesses, institutional investors, heads of public-sector organizations, university researchers and regulatory experts : [https://igopp.org/en/igopp/board-of-directors/mary-ann-bell/ Mary-Ann Bell], [https://igopp.org/en/igopp/board-of-directors/isabelle-courville/ Isabelle Courville], [https://igopp.org/en/igopp/board-of-directors/helene-desmarais/ Hélène Desmarais], [https://igopp.org/en/igopp/board-of-directors/paule-dore/ Paule Doré], [[Robert_G_Greenhill|Robert Greenhill]], [[Stephen_A._Jarislowsky|Stephen Jarislowsky]], [https://igopp.org/en/igopp/board-of-directors/michel-l-magnan-ph-d-fcpa-auditor-fca-asc-c-dir/ Michel Magnan], [https://igopp.org/en/igopp/board-of-directors/claudine-mangen/ Claudine Mangen], [https://igopp.org/en/igopp/board-of-directors/andrew-t-molson/ Andrew T. Molson], [https://igopp.org/en/igopp/board-of-directors/louis-morisset/ Louis Morisset], [https://igopp.org/en/igopp/board-of-directors/michel-nadeau/ Michel Nadeau], [https://igopp.org/en/igopp/board-of-directors/robert-parizeau/ Robert Parizeau], [https://igopp.org/en/igopp/board-of-directors/guylaine-saucier/ Guylaine Saucier] and [https://igopp.org/en/igopp/board-of-directors/sebastian-van-berkom/ Sebastian Van Berkom].

{{EngvarB|date=January 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Infobox Government agency | agency_name = [[Government of Ireland]]
National Security Committee |type = Committee | seal = File:Coat of arms of Ireland.svg | seal_width = 140px | formed = 1974{{cite news|last1=Murphy|first1=Michael|title=State security: why we’re at risk|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/opinion/state-security-why-we-re-at-risk-1.2001422|accessdate=11 July 2015|work=The Irish Times|date=15 November 2014}} | preceding1 = | jurisdiction = | headquarters = | employees = | budget = | image = | chief1_position = Secretary General to the Government and [[Department of the Taoiseach]], Chair | chief1_name = [[Martin Fraser]] | chief2_position = | chief2_name = | parent_department = [[Department of the Taoiseach]] | website = }} [[File:Dublin-Dept-Of-Taoiseach-2012.JPG|thumbnail|The National Security Committee meets at [[Government Buildings]] in Dublin]] The '''National Security Committee''' ('''NSC''') of Ireland is a secretive inter-departmental committee responsible for ensuring that the [[Taoiseach]] (Prime Minister of Ireland) and [[Government of Ireland]] are kept informed of high-level [[national security]], intelligence and defence issues, and the state's response to them.{{cite web|title=Annual Report 2013|url=http://www.military.ie/fileadmin/user_upload/images/Info_Centre/documents/Annual_Reports/2013_Annual_Report_English_Version.pdf|publisher=Department of Defence and Defence Forces|accessdate=11 July 2015}}{{cite web|title=National Security Committee|url=https://www.kildarestreet.com/debates/?id=2010-11-02.6.0|publisher=Kildare Street|accessdate=11 July 2015}} The National Security Committee is chaired by the [[Secretary-General|Secretary General]] to the Irish Government/Secretary General of the [[Department of the Taoiseach]], and comprises; the [[Garda Commissioner|Commissioner]] of the [[Garda Síochána]], the Secretary General of the [[Department of Justice and Equality]], the [[Chief of Staff of the Defence Forces (Ireland)|Chief of Staff]] of the [[Defence Forces (Ireland)|Defence Forces]], the Secretary General of the [[Department of Defence (Ireland)|Department of Defence]], and the Secretary General of the [[Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (Ireland)|Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade]].{{cite web|title=Defence Forces Strategy Statement 2003–2005|url=http://www.military.ie/fileadmin/user_upload/images/Info_Centre/Docs2/strategy_03-05.pdf|publisher=Defence Forces Ireland|accessdate=11 July 2015}}{{cite web|title=Annual Report to the Minister for Defence for 2007|url=http://www.military.ie/fileadmin/user_upload/images/Info_Centre/documents/Annual_Reports/ar_2007_en.pdf|publisher=Department of Defence and Defence Forces|accessdate=11 July 2015}} The [[Revenue Commissioners]], [[Department of Communications, Energy and Natural Resources]] and [[Department of Transport, Tourism and Sport]] also have intelligence roles, but are not full members of the NSC. The NSC meets on a regular scheduled basis and convenes additionally when required. The Taoiseach's office is responsible for calling meetings of the NSC.{{cite news|last1=Roche|first1=Barry|title=Coveney plays down threat of Paris-type attacks in Ireland|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/ireland/irish-news/coveney-plays-down-threat-of-paris-type-attacks-in-ireland-1.2430900|accessdate=15 November 2015|work=The Irish Times|date=15 November 2015}} It was established in 1974 tasked with advising the Taoiseach and cabinet on high-level security issues. The committee receives threat assessments from the Garda Commissioner and the Chief of Staff, and reviews the overall security situation in the domestic and international environment.{{cite web|title=Strategy Statement 2008 – 2010|url=http://www.military.ie/fileadmin/user_upload/images/Info_Centre/Docs2/Strateg_08-10en.pdf|publisher=Department of Defence and Defence Forces|accessdate=11 July 2015}} The [[Minister for Defence (Ireland)|Minister for Defence]] receives monthly intelligence, state security and defence briefings from the [[Director of Military Intelligence (Ireland)|Director of Military Intelligence]].{{cite web|title=Department of Defence and Defence Forces Annual Report 2012|url=http://www.military.ie/fileadmin/user_upload/images/Info_Centre/documents/Annual_Reports/an_report_2012_en.pdf|publisher=military.ie|accessdate=11 July 2015}} ==Members== {| class="wikitable" ! colspan="2" | Structure of the Irish National Security Committee |- ! Chair | Secretary General to the [[Government of Ireland]] |- ! Statutory Attendees | Secretary General of the [[Department of Justice and Equality]]
[[Garda Commissioner|Commissioner]] of the [[Garda Síochána]]
Secretary General of the [[Department of Defence (Ireland)|Department of Defence]]
[[Chief of Staff of the Defence Forces (Ireland)|Chief of Staff]] of the [[Defence Forces (Ireland)|Defence Forces]]
Secretary General of the [[Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (Ireland)|Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade]] |- ! Intelligence Advisor | [[Director of Military Intelligence (Ireland)|Director of Military Intelligence]] |- ! Regular Attendees | [[Revenue Commissioners]]
[[Department of Communications, Energy and Natural Resources]]
[[Department of Transport, Tourism and Sport]] |} ==Terrorism threat level== The constituents of the National Security Committee deliberate on the Republic of Ireland's ''International Terror Threat Level''. Five levels are used to grade the international threat of a terrorist attack to Ireland; low, moderate, substantial, severe and critical. The gradings are based on a series of factors, including information supplied by international authorities.{{cite news|last1=Williams|first1=Paul|title=Intelligence units monitor 40 suspected Isil supporters|url=http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/intelligence-units-monitor-40-suspected-isil-supporters-34359737.html|accessdate=17 January 2016|publisher=Irish Independent|date=13 January 2016}} The threat level is administered by the Garda Síochána. '''International Terror Threat Level:''' * '''Low''' – An attack is deemed unlikely. * '''Moderate''' – An attack is possible, but not likely. * '''Substantial''' – An attack is a strong possibility. * '''Severe''' – An attack is highly likely. * '''Critical''' – An attack is imminent.{{cite news|last1=O'Keeffe|first1=Cormac|title=What is the reality of the threat posed by Islamic extremists in Ireland?|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/viewpoints/analysis/what-is-the-reality-of-the-threat-posed-by-islamic-extremists-in-ireland-396021.html|accessdate=11 May 2016|work=Irish Examiner|date=2 May 2016}} The International Terror Threat Level was raised from low to moderate following the [[January 2015 Île-de-France attacks]].{{cite news|last1=Brady|first1=Tom|title=Garda snipers and extra Army bomb disposal officers in place for 1916 commemorations|url=http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/garda-snipers-and-extra-army-bomb-disposal-officers-in-place-for-1916-commemorations-34564635.html|accessdate=25 March 2016|publisher=Irish Independent|date=23 March 2016}} ==National Civil Aviation Security Committee== The '''National Civil Aviation Security Committee''' ('''NCASC''') is a standing committee established in 1974.{{cite web|title=Departmental Bodies of the Department of Transport|url=https://www.kildarestreet.com/wrans/?id=2010-11-02.1301.0|publisher=kildarestreet.com|accessdate=11 July 2015}} The purpose of the NCASC is to advise the Irish government and civil aviation industry of security policy for civil aviation, to recommend and review security measures at airports and to co-ordinate the various interests involved. The National Civil Aviation Security Committee meets at a minimum biannually.{{cite web|title=Topical Issue Debate/State Airports|url=https://www.kildarestreet.com/debates/?id=2012-05-17.390.0|publisher=kildarestreet.com|accessdate=11 July 2015}} The NCASC comprises senior representatives of government departments, Irish airports, Irish airlines, the Garda Síochána, the Defence Forces, [[An Post]], Customs & Excise (Revenue), the [[Irish Aviation Authority]] (IAA), and the Irish Airline Pilots Association (IALPA). The committee was established under the National Civil Aviation Security Programme (NCASP) which is classified on security grounds, and therefore the deliberations of the committee are confidential.{{cite web|title=Statement on Dublin Airport by the Chairman of the National Civil Aviation Security Committee |url=http://www.merrionstreet.ie/en/Category-Index/Transport/Ports-Airports/statement-on-dublin-airport-by-the-chairman-of-the-national-civil-aviation-security-committee.html|publisher=Merrion Street|accessdate=11 July 2015}} ==Continuity of government== The National Security Committee is the conduit for officials to communicate with the Taoiseach and/or cabinet members if their minister – the normal channel – became unavailable (or was killed). In preparation for such extreme events drafts of emergency powers legislation have been drawn up in secret by officials from the Department of Justice, including legislation to deal with circumstances such as an attack on cabinet involving numerous deaths.{{cite book|last1=Mulqueen|first1=Michael|title=Re-evaluating Irish national security policy : affordable threats?|date=2009|publisher=Manchester University Press|location=Manchester|isbn=978-0-7190-8027-2}} ==Government Security Committee== In July 2017, a new Government Security Committee designated '''Cabinet Committee F''' (named after the room in which it held its first meeting) was established. Chaired by [[Taoiseach]] [[Leo Varadkar]], the new committee is modelled on the British government [[Cabinet Office Briefing Room|COBRA]] crisis management committee with the aim of bringing together more senior cabinet-level ministers on matters of state security. Its inaugural meeting was attended by the [[Tánaiste]]; Minister of State at the [[Department of Defence (Ireland)|Department of Defence]]; Ministers and senior officials from the Departments of [[Department of Justice and Equality|Justice & Equality]]; Defence; [[Department of Jobs, Enterprise and Innovation|Enterprise & Innovation]]; [[Department of Finance (Ireland)|Finance]] and [[Department of Public Expenditure and Reform|Public Expenditure & Reform]]; [[Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (Ireland)|Foreign Affairs & Trade]]; [[Department of Health (Ireland)|Health]]; [[Department of Housing, Planning, Community and Local Government|Housing, Planning & Local Government]]; [[Department of Communications, Climate Action and Environment|Communications, Climate Action & Environment]]; and [[Department of Transport, Tourism and Sport|Transport, Tourism & Sport]], where senior Defence Forces and Garda officers briefed them on the international terrorism threat.{{cite news|last1=Murtagh|first1=Peter|title=Army Ranger Wing to get higher anti-terrorist profile|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/ireland/irish-news/army-ranger-wing-to-get-higher-anti-terrorist-profile-1.3166803|accessdate=26 July 2017|work=The Irish Times|date=26 July 2017}}{{cite news|title=Taoiseach convenes first meeting of Government Security Committee|url=http://www.merrionstreet.ie/en/News-Room/Releases/Taoiseach_convenes_first_meeting_of_Government_Security_Committee.html|accessdate=26 July 2017|publisher=MerrionStreet|date=20 July 2017}} ==See also== * [[Director of Military Intelligence (Ireland)]] * [[Office of Emergency Planning (Ireland)|Office of Emergency Planning]] (OEP) ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:National security]] [[Category:National security councils]] [[Category:Irish spies]] [[Category:Government agencies of the Republic of Ireland]] [[Category:Military of the Republic of Ireland]] [[Category:Counter-terrorist organizations]]

'''IJCSN [[Academic journal|Journal]]''' - International [[Academic journal|Journal]] of Computer Science and Network (IJCSN) is an open source online peer reviewed computer science journal launched by D-LAR Labs (Digital Library of Academic Research) publisher that publishes Review/Research articles which contribute new theoretical results in all areas of Computer Science, Communication Network and Information Technologies. International Journal of Computer Science and Network.
==Founding== '''IJCSN Journal''' was founded in 2011 by Digital Library of Academic Research, an Indian Digital Library.
==Subject areas== IJCSN Journal is dedicated to publish original research articles in various fields like Foundations of High-performance Computing, Neural Network, [[Digital Signal Processing]], Mobile Computing / Technology, 3G/4G Network Evolution, Mobile Computing for e-Commerce, Authentication/Authorization Issues, IDS/Firewall, Anti-Spam mail, Anti-virus issues, e-Business Applications, Scientific and Engineering Computing, Complex Systems: Modeling and Simulation, [[Data Visualization]] and Virtual Reality, Hardware/Software Co-design and VLSI Support, [[Computational Intelligence]], Granular Computing and Soft Computing, Architectures and Computation Models, Compiler, Hardware and OS Issues, Artificial Intelligence& Pattern/Image Recognition, Data Base Management Systems (DBMS) & Information Retrieval, Ad-Hoc, Mobile, Wireless Networks and Mobile Computing, Quality of Services and Communication Protocol, CDMA/GSM Communication Protocol, Cryptography and Foundation of Computer Security, PKI(Public Key Infrastructures), Wireless Security System, Advanced Numerical Algorithms, Hybrid Computational Methods, Problem Solving Environments, Web- and Grid-based Computing and Simulation, Possibility Theory, Bayes Network and Hidden Markov Models, New Algorithmic Approaches to Computational Kernels and Applications, Computational Science Aspects of Data Mining, [[Information Retrieval]] and Text Mining, and any other topics relevant to latest trends in Computer Science and Information Technologies.
==Publications== * [http://ijcsn.org/articles/0205/Sentiment-Analysis-Towards-Harvesting-Opinions-from-the-Net.html Sentiment Analysis-Towards Harvesting Opinions from the Net] * [http://ijcsn.org/articles/0205/State-of-the-Art-in-Semantic-Web-Search-Techniques-for-Arabic-Language.html State of the Art in Semantic Web Search Techniques for Arabic Language] * [http://ijcsn.org/articles/0205/Need-of-an-English-Language-Laboratory-in-Engineering-Universities.html Need of an English Language Laboratory in Engineering Universities] * [http://ijcsn.org/articles/0205/Eyes-Detection-by-Pulse-Coupled-Neural-Networks.html Eyes Detection by Pulse Coupled Neural Networks] * [http://ijcsn.org/articles/0205/Reinforcement-Learning-Framework-for-Opportunistic-Routing-in-WSNs.html Reinforcement Learning Framework for Opportunistic Routing in WSNs] * [http://ijcsn.org/articles/0205/Review-on-Fragment-Allocation-by-using-Clustering-Technique-in-Distributed-Database-System.html Review on Fragment Allocation by using Clustering Technique in Distributed Database System] * [http://ijcsn.org/articles/0205/Sentiment-Analysis-Towards-Harvesting-Opinions-from-the-Net.html Sentiment Analysis-Towards Harvesting Opinions from the Net] * [http://ijcsn.org/articles/0205/Sentiment-Analysis-Towards-Harvesting-Opinions-from-the-Net.html Sentiment Analysis-Towards Harvesting Opinions from the Net] For more, visit [http://ijcsn.org/publications.html IJCSN Publications]

[[Socialism]] | coalition = | international = ''none'' | european = ''none'' | europarl = ''no MEPs'' | website = http://www.sardignanatzione.it | colorcode = red | country = Sardinia }} '''Sardinia Nation''' ({{lang-sc|Sardigna Natzione}}, SN) is a minor [[separatism|separatist]] and [[socialism|socialist]] [[list of political parties in Sardinia|political party in Sardinia]], [[Italy]]. Its long-time leader is [[Bustianu Cumpostu]]. ==History== The party was founded by [[Anghelu Caria]] in 1994, in continuity with the [[Independentist Sardinian Party]] (PSIn), of which Caria had been founder and leader. After Caria's sudden death, [[Bustianu Cumpostu]] was elected new leader by defeating [[Gavino Sale]], who would lead the party's left-wing faction for five years, before leaving in 2001. In the [[Italian general election, 1996 (Sardinia)|1996 general election]] SN won 4.3% in single-seat constituencies (11.6% in [[Tortolì]] and 9.6% in [[Iglesias, Sardinia|Iglesias]]), despite being present only in ten constituencies out of fourteen, and 2.3% for proportional representation, due to competition from the [[Sardinian Action Party]] (PSd'Az), which gained 3.8%.http://elezionistorico.interno.it/enti.php?tp=C&dt=21/04/1996&cta=I&ord=3&sut1=26&sut2=0&sut3=0&sut4=0&liv=1&descE=%20Circoscrizione:%20SARDEGNA&descA= In the [[Sardinian regional election, 1999|1999 Sardinian regional election]] SN had its best result ever, as Cumpostu received 5.8% of the vote for president, while the PSd'Az gained 8.3% with [[Franco Meloni]]. However, as Cumpostu did not surpass the 6% threshold and the party list stopped at 1.8%, the party did not get into the Regional Council. Both for the [[Italian general election, 2001 (Sardinia)|2001 general election]] and the [[Sardinian regional election, 2004|2004 regional election]] SN formed an alliance with the PSd'Az. This led Sale, who refused any collaboration with not parties being considered not fully committed to independence, and his faction to leave the party in 2001 to form [[Independence Republic of Sardinia]] (iRS). In the election the Sardist electorate was very fragmented (also because of the presence of the [[Sardinian Democratic Union]], UDS, which ran on a "nationalist" platform) and most of SN former voters voted Sale for President (1.9%) and the iRS party list (0.7%), while only a minority voted for SN (0.4%). SN won 1.1% of the vote in the [[Italian general election, 2006 (Sardinia)|2006 general election]] and 0.7% in [[Italian general election, 2008 (Sardinia)|2008]]. In the [[Sardinian regional election, 2009|2009 regional election]] the party formed a "nationalist" left-wing alliance with [[To the Left for Independence]], a [[communism|communist]] party, and other minor separatist groups, but gained only 0.5%, while Sale (iRS) 3.1%. In the [[Sardinian regional election, 2014|2014 regional election]] the party unsuccessfully sought to join the coalition led by [[Michela Murgia]] (centred on [[Project Republic of Sardinia]]), in list with alike separatist parties, and finally decided not to take part to the election.http://www.unionesarda.it/articolo/politica_italiana/2014/01/14/sardigna_natzione_fuori_dalle_elezioni_rifiutati_da_sardegna_possibile-1-349682.html ==Popular support== The electoral results of SN in [[Sardinia]] since 1994 are shown in the table below. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ||'''1994 regional'''||'''1996 general'''||'''1999 regional'''||'''1999 European'''||'''2001 general'''||'''2004 European'''||'''2004 regional'''||'''2006 general'''||'''2008 general'''||'''2009 regional'''||'''2009 European'''||'''2013 general'''||'''2014 regional'''||'''2014 European''' |- ||1.2This result refers to the provincial lists of the party, whose regional list gained 2.7% of the vote.||2.3This result refers to proportional representation; SN gained 4.3% of the vote in single-seat constituencies.||1.8This result refers to the party list; [[Bustianu Cumpostu]], candidate for President, won 5.8% of the vote.||-||-The party formed a joint list with the [[Sardinian Action Party]] that gained 3.4% for proportional representation and 4.1% in single-seat constituencies in Sardinia.||-||0.4||1.1||0.7||0.5This result refers to the joint list Sardinia Nation formed with [[To the Left for Independence]] and other minor secessionist groups.||-||-||-||- |- |} ==Leadership== *Coordinator: [[Anghelu Caria]] (1994–1996), [[Bustianu Cumpostu]] (1996–present) ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.sardignanatzione.it Official website] [[Category:Political parties in Sardinia]] [[Category:Sardinian nationalist parties]] [[Category:Separatism in Italy]] [[Category:Secessionist organizations in Europe]] [[Category:Political parties established in 1994]]

'''Savas Mihail Matsas''' (or '''Savas Michael Matsas''' or '''Savas Michael-Matsas''';<ref>[http://www.internationalviewpoint.org/IMG/pdf/IV382.pdf Letter to support the creation of the Livio Maitan study centre (Retrieved July 8, 2013)]</ref> {{lang-el|Σάββας Μιχαήλ Μάτσας}}; born as '''Sabetai Benaki Matsas''' (Σαμπετάι Μπενάκη Μάτσας)<ref name=enet>{{cite web|url=http://www.enet.gr/online/online_issues?pid=51&dt=22/12/2006&id=76084356 |title=Homo Poeticus |accessdate=2/12/2008 |author=Νίκος Ντόκας, Βασίλης Καλαμαράς |date=2006-12-22 |work=Βιβλιοθήκη |publisher=Ελευθεροτυπία}}</ref> 1947, [[Athens]]) is a Greek intellectual, leader of the [[Workers Revolutionary Party (Greece)]]. He is an [[antizionism|antizionist]] and [[Internationalist–defencist schism|internationalist]] author of a considerable work of culture about literature, philosophy, religion and [[class struggle]]. He has been trying to offer "a reinterpretation of the [[Marxist schools of thought#Marxism-Leninism|revolutionary theory]] and [[marxism]] from the perspective of [[messianism]] and [[Kabbalah|Jewish mystic]], and vice versa".<ref name=lowy>Löwy, M. (2013, July 7). ¿El antisemitismo impone la ley? [Does antisemitism impose the law?], ''La Jornada'', sección Política, p. 14. (in Spanish) (Retrieved July 7, 2013)</ref> His position may be classified as that of a "religious atheism" or else of a "profane messianism"<ref name=lowy />
==Political prosecution== In 2009, the far-right [[Golden Dawn (Greece)|Golden Dawn]] party filed, before the Greek justice, many documents against several left-wing Greek authors. The police wanted to interrogate all of them, but they jointly agreed not to appear in court and jointly signed a document stating they legally rejected the accusations. After reviewing the documentation, two of them were brought to justice by the Attorney General: Savas Matsas and Constantin Motzouri, the former rector of the [[National Technical University of Athens]]. There was an international petition in his defence.<ref>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2013/sep/01/absurd-golden-dawn-hound-friend-court Guardian article oln case</ref><ref>https://linksunten.indymedia.org/de/node/91006 Interview with him about the case</ref><ref>[http://www.ekathimerini.com/4dcgi/_w_articles_wsite1_1_04/07/2013_507578 July 4, 2013 note about Savas Mikhail prosecution (Retrieved July 7, 2013)]</ref><ref>http://mtl-fi.org/2013/06/29/greece-stop-the-trial-of-savas-matsas/ Stop the Trial of Savas Matsas</ref><ref>http://socialistworker.org/2013/08/19/help-against-the-greek-fascists He needs your help against the fascists</ref><ref>https://www.facebook.com/gerdowning/posts/10201868529822843 statement by British supporters</ref><ref>http://po.org.ar/blog/2013/06/27/grecia-por-el-desprocesamiento-de-savas-matsas/ article (Spanish)</ref><ref>http://www.pclavoratori.it/files/index.php?c3:o3400 article (Italian)</ref>
On 4 September 2013, an Athens court acquitted Matsas and Moutzouris of all charges.<ref>{{cite news|title=Court acquits former rector, leftist of charges brought against them in lawsuits filed by Golden Dawn|url=http://www.ekathimerini.com/4dcgi/_w_articles_wsite1_1_04/09/2013_517124|accessdate=5 September 2013|newspaper=Ekathimerini|date=4 September 2013}}</ref><ref>http://www.enetenglish.gr/?i=news.en.article&id=1451</ref><ref> http://www.eek.gr/index.php/englishtext/1856-the-trial-of-september-3-4-against-the-eek EEK statement following their acquittal</ref>
==Works== *''Figures du Messianique'' (1999) (A compilation of essays published in that year; in French) *''Golem. A propos du sujet et d’autres fantômes'' (2010) (About Golem, Kafka, Hölderlin, Lacan, Philippe Lacoue-Labarthe, Hegel, Marx and modern Greek poets such as [[Andreas Embirikos]], universal literature and revolutionary marxism.
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==Links== *[http://krasnoe.tv/node/23964 Fascism in Europe. Lecture of Savas Matsas (Greece)] {{ref-en}}{{ref-ru}}

The '''staircase model''' is a psychological explanation as to why out of large numbers of disgruntled people in society, only a very small minority end up committing acts of [[terrorism]]. It was proposed in 2005 by [[Fathali M. Moghaddam]] in his paper "The Staircase to Terrorism".<ref name=staircase>{{cite journal |last=Moghaddam |first=Fathali |authorlink=Fathali M. Moghaddam |date=Feb–Mar 2005 |title=The Staircase to Terrorism |journal=[[American Psychologist]] |publisher= |volume=60 |issue=2 |pages=161–169 |doi=10.1037/0003-066x.60.2.161}}</ref> The model involves a metaphorical staircase, where each step is influenced by a specific psychological process. It is proposed that the higher an individual moves up the staircase, the fewer alternatives to violence they will see, ultimately resulting in the destruction of themselves, others, or both.<ref name=oxford/>
==Background== Moghaddam observed that societal-level variables, such as lack of democratic processes, [[social inequality]], availability of weapons and rapid demographic changes, do not explain why only a small percentage of people living under the same adverse conditions end up committing acts of violence against innocent targets. He proposed the staircase model to explain this phenomenon, describing the pathway to terrorism as a narrowing staircase, that very few people reach the top of.<ref name=intro>{{cite book |last1=Hewstone |first1=Miles |authorlink1=Miles Hewstone |last2=Stroebe |first2=Wolfgang |author-link2= Wolfgang Stroebe|last3=Jonas |first3=Klaus |date=May 14, 2012 |title=An Introduction to Social Psychology|edition=5th|publisher=BPS Blackwell |pages=305–306 |isbn=978-1444335446}}</ref>
==Model== The model involves six floors.<ref name=staircase/><ref name=oxford/><ref name=intro/><ref name=scand/> [[File:Staircase model.png|thumb|Diagram of the staircase model]]
===Ground floor=== The ground floor is inhabited by all members of society. All members of society evaluate their [[Standard of living|living conditions]] in terms of fairness. People will remain on the ground floor as long as they consider their living conditions to be fair. Those who perceive injustice move onto the first floor.<ref name=staircase/><ref name=intro/>
===First floor=== On the first floor, people consider their options for improving their situation. People who find options to improve their individual situation and influence decision-makers leave the staircase at this floor in order to pursue non-violent paths. People who are unsatisfied with their available options move onto the second floor.<ref name=staircase/><ref name=intro/>
===Second floor=== It is here that feelings of both anger and frustration over not being able to improve the situation instigate a search for a target to blame. This target can either be a direct opponent, such as a government, or a third party to whom aggression is displaced, such as an [[Ethnic group|ethnic]] or religious group. People who are persuaded that they have an enemy toward whom they can direct their [[aggression]], will proceed to the third floor.<ref name=staircase/><ref name=intro/>
===Third floor=== People who arrive here have already developed a readiness towards violence. These feelings can be capitalised on by a violent organisation that is offering a sense of 'moral engagement' to potential recruits. Within these organisations violent actions against a perceived enemy are regarded as acceptable or even as one's duty. Potential recruits are offered a new social identity as members of a selective [[Ingroups and outgroups|ingroup]] who aim to bring justice to the world. People who find this offer appealing will move on to the fourth floor.<ref name=staircase/><ref name=intro/>
===Fourth floor=== It is here that thinking such as 'us' versus 'them' is promoted. Recruits are isolated from friends and family, strict secrecy is imposed and the legitimacy of the organisation is emphasised. People who reach this floor will rarely withdraw and exit the staircase alive. They will move onto the fifth floor if an opportunity to do so presents.<ref name=staircase/><ref name=intro/>
===Fifth floor=== It is here that the violent act is carried out. In order to be as effective as possible, any inhibition about killing innocent people must be overcome. This is done via two means. [[Categorization|Categorisation]] stresses the differentiation between ingroup and out group, and [[Distancing (psychology)|distancing]] exaggerates the differences between the ingroup and the perceived enemy.<ref name=staircase/><ref name=intro/>
==Implications== Moghaddam states the model is not a formal one, but rather a metaphor for the purpose of providing general framework in order to organise current psychological knowledge regarding terrorism.<ref name=oxford>{{cite book |last1=Laurence |first1=Janice |last2=Matthews |first2=Michael |date=February 24, 2012 |title=The Oxford Handbook of Military Psychology |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yh9pAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA71 |location= |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] |page=71 |isbn= 978-0195399325 }}</ref> Nevertheless, the model is cited as useful for conceptualising the process that results in only a small number of individuals from a large group of disgruntled people will commit acts of violence against the innocent.<ref name=intro/> Moghaddam states that it is not enough to simply try and identify and stop potential terrorists, as this will only make room for new people to step forward, and instead proposes that the only way to end terrorism is by reforming the condition on the ground floor so that it is no longer perceived as unjust and hopeless by a large portion of society.<ref name=intro/>
The empirical basis of the model has been evaluated<ref name=oxford/> by an article in the [[Scandinavian Journal of Psychology]]. The findings state that whilst most of the processes in the model are supported by empirical evidence, the quantity and quality of said evidence varies.<ref name=scand>{{cite journal |last=Ragnhild |first=Lygre |last2= |first2= |date=2011 |title=Terrorism as a process: A critical review of Moghaddam's 'Staircase to Terrorism' |url= |journal= Scandinavian Journal of Psychology |volume=52 |issue=6 |page=615 |doi= }}</ref> Whilst praising Moghaddam's model for emphasising potential mechanisms for future study, the review concludes that the staircase model may not be the right metaphor for summarising the phenomena of terrorism, citing a lack of evidence for transition between the floors, and the possibility that some floors and corresponding processes from the model could be removed entirely due to a lack of empirical evidence.<ref name=scand/>
==References== {{reflist}}

The '''State Secretary for Church Affairs''' (German: ''Staatssekretär für Kirchenfragen'') was the head of the Secretariat for Church Affairs in the former [[German Democratic Republic]]. The office was responsible for the relationship of the government toward churches and religious groups. Policy was set by the ruling [[Socialist Unity Party of Germany|Socialist Unity Party]] (SED), but direct contact with the churches and religious groups was essentially restricted to the Secretariat in order to preserve the SED's stance as [[Atheism|atheist]] and [[Antireligion|anti-religion]].
== Establishment and function == The office was established in 1957 following the example of the [[Soviet Union]] and other communist countries. The SED's goal was to prevent religious involvement in state affairs, particularly with regard to education and training of children and young people. The Secretary was responsible for maintaining the relationship between government and the churches and religious groups, but was kept weak with no power to set policy. Policy towards religion was set by the SED, whose leaders rarely met with religious leaders.<ref name="Cooke-Grix">Paul Cooke, Jonathan Grix (Editors), [https://books.google.com/books?id=PAR5nQudwUUC&pg=PA104&lpg=PA104#v=onepage&q&f=false ''East Germany: Continuity and Change''] Editions Rodopi B.V., Amsterdam - Atlanta, GA (2000), pp. 104-105. {{ISBN|90-420-0579-3}} Retrieved October 16, 2013</ref> This arrangement allowed the SED to maintain its appearance as an "atheistic party against the Church". However, it also created a situation where, not having direct contact with the churches, the party was forced to rely on other's reports for what was actually going on with the churches, reports that often minimized or omitted serious criticism of the communist government "in order to avoid excited or angry decisions, or to confirm the predominant picture among the recipients of the report of harmonious societal development."<ref>Horst Dohle, quoted in: Paul Cooke, Jonathan Grix (2000), [https://books.google.com/books?id=PAR5nQudwUUC&pg=PA105&lpg=PA105#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 105] Retrieved October 17, 2013</ref>
In addition to maintaining relationships with the churches, the Secretary was to ensure that the laws and ordinances kept pace with the development of the socialist state.<ref name="wallmann">Johannes Wallmann. ''Kirchengeschichte Deutschlands seit der Reformation''. Tübingen (2006) p. 300. {{de icon}}</ref> The SED expected religion to die out over time and sought to restrict the churches to conducting rites and services.<ref name="mm-sm-haw">Michael Mertes, Steven Muller, Heinrich August Winckler (Editors), [https://books.google.com/books?id=FJaHiGHRM6kC&pg=PA271&lpg=PA271#v=onepage&q&f=false ''In Search of Germany''] Transaction Publishers. New Brunswick, New Jersey (1996), p. 271. {{ISBN|1-56000-880-6}} Retrieved October 16, 2013</ref> Church representatives viewed the office as the "State Secretariat Against Church Affairs".<ref name="wallmann" />
== Control and persecution == A list, based on religions recognized by the post-war [[Soviet Military Administration in Germany|Soviet Military Administration]] was drawn up by the [[Ministry of the Interior (East Germany)|Ministry of the Interior]]. Those that were on the list were allowed to hold church services,<ref name="GWS-22">Gregory W. Sandford, ''Christian Science in East Germany: The Church that Came in from the Cold'' (2013), p. 22</ref> though there were waves of persecution in 1953 and 1958, including arrests of ministers and others, and show trials.<ref name="mm-sm-haw" />
Two religions were kept off the list, [[Jehovah's Witnesses]] and [[Christian Science]]. Jehovah's Witnesses were denied approval based on their "rejection of secular authority". Christian Science was denied because of the religion's affiliation with the United States and a Nazi-era law related to medical practice.<ref name="GWS-7">Gregory W. Sandford (2013), pp. 7-8</ref> Christian Science was later granted official recognition in November 1989, just prior to the [[fall of the Berlin Wall]].<ref name="GWS-123">Gregory W. Sandford (2013), p. 123</ref>
== State Secretaries == * 1957-1960: [[Werner Eggerath]] * 1960-1979: [[Hans Seigewasser]] * 1979-1988: [[Klaus Gysi]] * 1988-1989: [[Kurt Löffler]] * 1989-1990: [[Lothar de Maizière]]
== References == {{reflist|2}}
== Further reading == * DDR-Handbuch, Volume 2, M-Z. Cologne (1985) p.1299f

{{Orphan|date=April 2014}}
The '''Student Adaptation to College Questionnaire''' (abbreviated '''SACQ''') is a 67-item [[self-report inventory]] designed by Robert W. Baker and Bohdan Siryk and published by [[Western Psychological Services]] in 1987 (manual published 1989). The questionnaire is proprietary and copies of the questionnaire as well as the manual can be purchased from the WPS website.<ref name=official>{{cite web|url=http://www.wpspublish.com/store/p/2949/student-adaptation-to-college-questionnaire-sacq|title = Student Adaptation to College Questionnaire™ (SACQ™)|publisher = [[Western Psychological Services]]|year = 1987|accessdate = April 22, 2014}}</ref>
==History==
In a 1984 paper, Baker and Siryk described the results of a 52-item [[self-report inventory]] that used a [[Likert scale]]. They had administered this inventory to 734 students, and their paper discussed the reliability and validity of the data thus obtained.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Measuring adjustment to college|last= Baker|first = Robert W.|last2 = Siryk|first2 = Bohdan|journal = [[Journal of Counseling Psychology]]|volume = 31|issue = 2|date = April 1984|pages = 179–189|doi=10.1037/0022-0167.31.2.179}}</ref> This would later grow into the Student Adaptation to Colleges Questionnaire.<ref name=official/>
==Description of the questionnaire==
The questionnaire is a 67-item self-report inventory that assesses overall adjustment to college, as well as adjustment in four specific areas:<ref name=doc>{{cite web|url=http://v-psyche.com/doc/IQ/Student%20Adaptation%20to%20College%20Questionnaire.doc|title = Student Adaptation to College Questionnaire|last = Baker|first = Robert W.|last2 = Siryk|first2 = Bohdan|accessdate = April 22, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wpspublish.com/store/Images/Downloads/Product/SACQ_Sample-Test-Report.pdf|title = SACQ Sample Report|last = Baker|first = Robert W.|last2 = Siryk|first2 = Bohdan|publisher = [[Western Psychological Services]]|accessdate = April 22, 2014}}</ref>
* Academic adjustment * Personal-emotional adjustment * Social adjustment * Attachment (to the institution)
The authors claim that if the questionnaire is used at the time people enter college, it can be used for the early detection of potential adjustment problems and can increase the retention of students who might otherwise drop out.<ref name=doc/>
==Reception==
===Academic research===
There is some academic research that relies on the SACQ and judges its usefulness. A 1992 paper by Krotseng used discriminant analysis to determine "(1) the extent to which the SACQ accurately predicts student departure for a private, comprehensive university; (2) SACQ items distinguishing nonpersisters; (3) use with an incoming class; and (4) evidence linking the SACQ with intervention strategies."<ref>{{cite journal|title = Predicting persistence from the student adaptation to college questionnaire: Early warning or siren song?|journal = [[Research in Higher Education]]|last = Krotseng|first= Marsha V.|date = February 1992|volume = 33|issue = 1|pages = 99–111|doi = 10.1007/BF00991974}}</ref> Another 1992 paper by Dahmus, Bernardin, and Bernardin discussed the SACQ's potential.<ref>{{cite journal|title = Student Adaptation to College Questionnaire|last = Dahmus|first = Sue|last2 = Bernardin|first2 = H. John|last3 = Bernardin|first3 = Kathleen|journal = [[Measurement and Evaluation in Counseling and Development]]|volume = 25|issue = 3|date = October 1992|pages = 139–142}}</ref>
A 1994 study by Gerdes and Mallinckrodt used SACQ data to measure the emotional, social, and academic adjustment of college students.<ref>{{cite journal|title = Emotional, Social, and Academic Adjustment of College Students: A Longitudinal Study of Retention|last = Gerdes|first = Hillary|last2 = Mallinckrodt|first2 = Brent|journal = [[Journal of Counseling and Development]]|date = January–February 1994|volume = 72|issue = 3|pages = 281–288|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/227841056_Emotional_Social_and_Academic_Adjustment_of_College_Students_A_Longitudinal_Study_of_Retention/file/72e7e51eda7747339c.pdf|doi=10.1002/j.1556-6676.1994.tb00935.x}}</ref>
A 2002 paper by Beyers and Goossens from the [[Katholieke Universiteit Leuven|Catholic University of Leuven]] considered the applicability of the SACQ to [[Europe]] and concluded: "With some reservations regarding the Academic Adjustment subscale, then, the SACQ seems to be a useful tool for research on university life among college students in Europe."<ref name=catholic>{{cite journal|title = Concurrent and predictive validity of the Student Adaptation to College Questionnaire in a sample of European freshman students|last = Beyers|first = Wim|last2 = Goossens|first2 = Luc|journal = [[Educational and Psychological Measurement]]|volume = 62|issue = 3|date = June 2002|pages = 525–536|accessdate = April 22, 2014|url = http://www.sagepub.com/bjohnsonstudy/articles/Beyers.pdf}}</ref>
The abstract of a 2012 meta-analysis by Credé and Niehorster (k = 237, N = 44,668) reads: "The review, based on studies using the Student Adaptation to College Questionnaire, is organized around three primary themes: (1) the structure of students’ adjustment to college, (2) the relationship of adjustment to college constructs with possible antecedents and correlates, and (3) the relationship of adjustment to college constructs with college grades and college retention. Meta-analytic results indicate that adjustment to college is multidimensional, predictive of college grades, and an unusually good predictor of college retention. Adjustment to college is also shown to be moderately related to individual traits, social support, and students’ relationships with their parents. Weaker relationships are evident with demographic variables, prior achievement, coping approaches, and variables that reflect students’ psychological independence from their parents. Theoretical and practical implications for the study of students’ adjustment to college, academic performance, and retention are discussed."<ref>{{cite journal|title = Adjustment to College as Measured by the Student Adaptation to College Questionnaire: A Quantitative Review of its Structure and Relationships with Correlates and Consequences|last = Credé|first = Marcus|last2 = Niehorster|first2 = Sarah|doi = 10.1007/s10648-011-9184-5|journal = [[Educational Psychology Review]]|volume = 24|issue = 1|pages = 133–165}}</ref>

{{Infobox religious biography |background = #FFD068 | color = black |name = Thích Huyền Quang |image= Ht huyenquang A4.jpg |caption = |birth name = Lê Đình Nhàn |birth_date = {{Birth date|1919|9|19|df=yes}} |birth_place = Bình Định Province, Vietnam, French Indochina |death_date = {{Death date and age|2008|7|5|1919|9|19|df=yes}} |death_place = Hồ Chí Minh City, Socialist Republic of Vietnam |nationality = Vietnamese |religion = [[Zen|Thiền (Zen)]] [[Buddhism]] |school = [[Rinzai school|Lâm Tế]] (Linji Chan School) |title =
Tăng Thống
(Patriarch)}} {{Vietnamese name|Thich|Quang}} '''Thích Huyền Quang''' (19 September 1919 – 5 July 2008[http://www.hdvnbtdt.org/article.php3?id_article=109 Vietnamese Federation For Fatherland's Integrity] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080807023142/http://www.hdvnbtdt.org/article.php3?id_article=109 |date=2008-08-07 }}) was a [[Vietnam]]ese [[Bhikkhu|Buddhist monk]], [[dissident]] and activist. At the time, he was the Patriarch of the Unified Buddhist Church of Vietnam, a currently banned organisation in his homeland. He was notable for his activism for human and religious rights in Vietnam. In 1977, Quang wrote a letter to then-[[Prime Minister of Vietnam|Prime Minister]] [[Phạm Văn Đồng]] detailing counts of oppression by the communist regime. For this, he and five other senior monks were arrested and detained. In 1982, he was arrested and put on permanent house arrest for opposition to governmental policy after publicly denouncing the establishment of the state-controlled Vietnam Buddhist Church.[http://www.iht.com/articles/reuters/2008/07/06/asia/OUKWD-UK-VIETNAM-MONK.php ''International Herald Tribune'' article: "Dissident patriarch of Vietnam Buddhist group dies"] In 2002, he was awarded the [[Homo Homini Award]] for his human rights activism by the Czech group [[People in Need (Czech Republic)|People in Need]], which he shared with [[Thích Quảng Độ]] and [[Nguyen Van Ly|Father Nguyễn Văn Lý]].{{cite web|url=http://www.clovekvtisni.cz/index2en.php?id=549|title=Previous Recipients of the Homo Homini Award|publisher=[[People In Need (Czech Republic)|People in Need]]|accessdate=17 April 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110501192644/http://www.clovekvtisni.cz/index2en.php?id=549|archivedate=1 May 2011|df=}} ==Death== Quang died peacefully on Saturday, 5 July 2008, aged 88, at his monastery.[http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5gF2QgSDrqIjSDLUO41UCREKZ4P9A Google News via AFP][https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/07/05/AR2008070500684.html?hpid=sec-religion Dissident Vietnamese monk dies in Vietnam][http://www.startribune.com/23516704.html ''Star Tribune'' article: "Patriarch of banned Vietnamese Buddhist church dies after years under house arrest"]{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/7501092.stm|title=Vietnamese dissident laid to rest|author=BBC News|accessdate=2008-07-20|date=2008-07-11}} His funeral was held on Friday, 11 July 2008, without incident.{{cite web|url=http://www.topnews.in/banned-vietnamese-monks-funeral-held-without-incident-252249|title=Banned Vietnamese monk's funeral held without incident|author=Sahil Nagpal|accessdate=2008-07-12|date=2008-07-11}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/obituaries/article4281357.ece ''The Times'' obituary for Thích Huyền Quang]

{{Tone|date=March 2009}} '''ToolBank''' is a registered term or 'word mark' registered with the U.S. Patent & Trademark Office used to identify the nonprofit tool lending program model created by the [http://atlanta.toolbank.org Atlanta Community ToolBank]. Each ToolBank increases the impact of its local charitable sector by lending tools to organizations for use in the fulfillment of their missions. The available inventory of a typical ToolBank includes tools for landscaping, carpentry, plumbing, masonry as well as power tools, ladders, wheelbarrows, and others. The Atlanta Community ToolBank is currently the largest ToolBank in existence, with over 200 tool types in its lending inventory. The available inventory of the Atlanta Community ToolBank can be found [http://atlanta.toolbank.org/Portals/18/TRF.pdf here]{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}. Nine ToolBanks are currently lending tools in Atlanta GA, Baltimore MD, Charlotte NC, Cincinnati OH, Houston TX, Phoenix AZ, Portland OR, Richmond VA, and Chicago, IL. The national network of ToolBanks is administered by the parent organization [http://www.toolbank.org ToolBank USA], which was founded in 2008 to replicate the impact of the Atlanta ToolBank in cities beyond Atlanta. In 2014, ToolBank USA launched ToolBank Disaster Services, a program to deliver tools to communities affected by disaster. ToolBanks loaned $5.8M worth of tools and equipment to charitable organizations in 2015. The ToolBank program model differs from the more common [[tool library]] model in that ToolBanks loan tools exclusively to other charitable organizations; ToolBank tools are not available to individuals. The ToolBank inventory is designated for the purpose of increasing the impact of the nonprofit sector and less formalized grassroots organizations. Typical borrowers of ToolBank tools include faith-based organizations, public schools, neighborhood organizations, public/private partnerships with community-oriented missions, social clubs with a service mission, gardening clubs, and others. Proof of charitable intent is verified prior to accessing ToolBank tools. The ToolBank performs three primary functions: 1. '''Tool Lending:''' The ToolBank lends tools of all kinds for use in volunteer projects, facility maintenance and improvement projects, community improvement events, and special events. 2. '''Tool Advocacy:''' ToolBank staff advocates for the complete and timely return of all borrowed tools, to guarantee the long-term sustainability of available inventory. Staff also seeks compensation for lost tools and tools returned late. 3. '''Tool Maintenance:''' The ToolBank performs [[Planned maintenance|routine maintenance]] and repairs on all equipment to ensure good condition and to extend the lifespan of the inventory. This function is typically performed by volunteers and community service workers. Through these three functions, local community organizations may benefit by:
ensuring that all participating volunteers are properly equipped;
engaging larger volunteer groups;
performing a broader scope of service projects;
engaging more highly skilled volunteers; and
eliminating tool purchase, repair, and storage costs. '''ToolBank''' is a registered mark of the Atlanta Community ToolBank.{{US servicemark|78934493}} The Atlanta Community ToolBank granted a Right to License to [http://www.toolbank.org ToolBank USA] in 2008. ToolBank USA is a nonprofit organization created in February 2008, charged with the successful nationwide replication of the ToolBank program model. ToolBank USA was launched by a founding grant from [http://www.homedepotfoundation.org/ The Home Depot Foundation]. == History == The '''Atlanta Community ToolBank''' originated in Atlanta GA as an offshoot of a charitable no-cost home repair program known as Community Reinvestment Inc (CRI), founded in 1990. CRI's tool inventory grew organically as a result of volunteers donating equipment in support of the program. Local neighborhood associations and churches periodically borrowed CRI's tools for their own cleanup days and volunteer events, giving rise to the core concept of the ToolBank. The specific origin of the term ToolBank is unknown; CRI began offering the ToolBank as a formal program in 1992. ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Image:ToolBank wheelbarrows.jpg]] [[Category:Community-building organizations]] [[Category:Neighborhood associations]] [[Category:Community development]] [[Category:Volunteering in the United States]] [[Category:Construction industry]]

[[Image:Albania Kosovo Locator.png|thumb|300px|right|Location of Albania (green) and Kosovo (orange) within [[Europe]].]] The '''[[Political union|unification]]''' of '''[[Albania]]''' and '''[[Kosovo]]''' is a political idea, revived since Kosovo [[Declaration of independence|declared independence]] in 2008.<ref name="WolchikCurry2011">{{cite book|author1=Sharon L. Wolchik|author2=Jane Leftwich Curry|title=Central and East European Politics: From Communism to Democracy|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BjVNJ1REkoEC&pg=PA390|year=2011|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|isbn=978-0-7425-6734-4|page=390|quote=Undoubtedly, Kosovo's independence has revived the idea of the national unification of Albanians}}</ref>
This idea has been brought into connection with the [[Irredentism|irredentist]] concept of [[Greater Albania]].<ref>{{cite book|author1=Tristan James Mabry|author2=John McGarry|title=Divided Nations and European Integration|year=2013|publisher=University of Pennsylvania Press|page=175}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author1=Lenard J. Cohen|author2=Jasna Dragović-Soso|title=State Collapse in South-Eastern Europe: New Perspectives on Yugoslavia's Disintegration|year=2008|publisher=Purdue University Press|page=194}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author1=Winston Langley|title=Encyclopedia of Human Rights Issues Since 1945|year=2013|publisher=Routledge}}</ref> About 90% of Kosovars are ethnic Albanians.
Polls supporting unification of Kosovo with Albania notwithstanding, the goal of Albanian politicians has been entrance into [[NATO]] and the [[EU]], rather than national unification.<ref name="Perritt2010">{{cite book|author=Henry H. Perritt|title=The Road to Independence for Kosovo: A Chronicle of the Ahtisaari Plan|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=f2nOTuF_KC0C&pg=PA94|year=2010|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-11624-4|page=94}}</ref> Some Roman Catholic and Orthodox Christian Albanians fear that any possible unification of Balkan areas that bring sizable numbers of Muslims into the new state may lead to an increasing "Muslimization" of Albania.<ref name="LesserLarrabee51">{{cite book|last=Lesser|first=Ian O.|last2=Larrabee|first2=F. Stephen|last3=Zanini|first3=Michele|last4=Vlachos-Dengler|first4=Katia|title=Greece's new geopolitics|year=2001|location=Santa Monica|publisher=Rand Corporation|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=4SNB8yXsTioC&pg=PA51&dq=Albania+Islam+geopolitics&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=Albania%20Islam%20geopolitics&f=false|isbn=9780833032331|ref=harv}}p. 51.</ref>
Unification in the eyes of many has already been achieved. Kosovo is predominately Albanian, and with the Republic of Albania shares some common administrative sectors such as education, policing, and foreign policy. Culture, heritage and trade have also been greatly unified between the two which also share an open border.
==History== During the [[1981 protests in Kosovo]] Yugoslavia feared a potential unification of Kosovo to Albania.<ref name="Clark2000">{{cite book|author=Howard Clark|title=Civil Resistance in Kosovo|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OTW9XKUmrxsC&pg=PA44|year=2000|publisher=Pluto Press|isbn=978-0-7453-1569-0|pages=44–}}</ref> In early 1990s Albanian politicians' statements were contradictory in regards.<ref name="Ahrens2007">{{cite book|author=Geert-Hinrich Ahrens|title=Diplomacy on the Edge: Containment of Ethnic Conflict and the Minorities Working Group of the Conferences on Yugoslavia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=b3fLRcHYSVAC&pg=PA323|date=6 March 2007|publisher=Woodrow Wilson Center Press|isbn=978-0-8018-8557-0|page=323|quote=CSCE mission of May 1992 judged that “on the question of the relations with Albania and of a possible unification, the answers were unclear, vague, and sometimes contraddictory}}</ref>
Political activist [[Ukshin Hoti]], founder of the [[Party of Albanian National Union]], eventually killed by Serbian police in 1999, was a very vocal supporter of the unification of Kosovo with Albania.<ref name="Krieger2001">{{cite book|author=Heike Krieger|title=The Kosovo Conflict and International Law: An Analytical Documentation 1974-1999|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-OhPTJn8ZWoC&pg=PA75|date=12 July 2001|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-80071-6|page=75}}</ref>
In 2001 [[Arben Imami]], a prominent Albanian politician, stated that unification of Kosovo with Albania should be a party goal, but was quickly criticized by his own party.<ref name="Koinova2013">{{cite book|author=Maria Koinova|title=Ethnonationalist Conflict in Postcommunist States: Varieties of Governance in Bulgaria, Macedonia, and Kosovo|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZwpuDCcN8AIC&pg=PA197|date=1 July 2013|publisher=University of Pennsylvania Press|isbn=978-0-8122-0837-5|page=197}}</ref>
The [[Ahtisaari Plan]] conditioned Kosovo's independence by adopting a multiethnic “Kosovar,” rather than an Albanian identity.<ref name="MabryMcGarry2013">{{cite book|author1=Tristan James Mabry|author2=John McGarry|author3=Margaret Moore|author4=Brendan O'Leary|title=Divided Nations and European Integration|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PFCbBW18yU4C&pg=PA182|date=30 May 2013|publisher=University of Pennsylvania Press|isbn=0-8122-4497-4|page=182}}</ref> Still, [[Gallup (company)|Gallup]] surveys revealed that 75% of Kosovo Albanians would prefer to live unified with Albania in a single country. The same support was seen in Albania where 68% of the citizens of Albania preferred a unification of Albania with Kosovo.<ref name="MabryMcGarry2013"/>
In 2017 some mainstream Albanian politicians such as [[Ben Blushi]] have come out in support of unification.<ref>https://koha.net/?id=27&l=153816</ref> In Kosovo, the largest opposition [[Vetëvendosje]] supports full Albanian unification.
==See also== {{Portal|Albania|Kosovo}} *[[Albanian nationalism]] *[[Greater Albania]] *[[Partition of Kosovo]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[https://www.reuters.com/article/us-albania-kosovo-unification-idUSKBN0MY18L20150407 Albania and Kosovo to unite, inside EU or not: Albanian PM] [[Category:Albanian irredentism]] [[Category:Albanian nationalism in Kosovo]] [[Category:National unifications|Albania and Kosovo]] [[Category:Political movements in Albania]] [[Category:Political movements in Kosovo]]
